Yes the game is old, and yes it doesn't look as nice as some of the other games but try to look past that. content:
Posted: October 23, 2014
It's everything we love about Star WarsI consider Jedi Outcast one of the best narrative Star Wars games ever. It's a simple and straightforward story, driven by the most classic of action hero motivations: revenge. It's a fine line to walk for our Jedi protagonist, Kyle Katarn. But he's no Luke Skywalker. From blasters, grenades, mines and more, no weapon goes left unused by Katarn in his quest for answers. And yes, that includes lightsabers.In fact, the Jedi Knight series still possesses the best lightsaber combat to date. Every swing, every thrust has the potential to be deadly, whether it's your lightsaber or your enemy's. No florescent batons here: swings cut through enemies neatly and quickly, as they should. Enable the dismemberment option for increased pandemonium.The greatest con might be the series' age. The visuals definitely diminished with time. But see if that still matters when the game hands you a lightsaber, a room full of Storm Troopers, and John William's score begins swelling. Oh, and did I mention they got Billy Dee Williams back to voice Lando? Because they got Billy Dee back to voice Lando. Awesome.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2015
												I'm sure this game was amazing at the time of release. You actually get to play as a Jedi with a lightsaber! And it's not just a click-to-melee-attack weapon, you can control the direction of the swing and stuff! The lightsaber combat would have been something new and innovative at the time. Unfortunately, once again I've ended up playing a sequel before a previous installment. I played Star Wars Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy already. I thought I'd done right this time, I mean, come on! That one is called Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy, this one is called Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast.With that polished experience in mind, I found Outcast's lightsaber combat frustrating. I know how to use the lightsaber but time and time again I found myself getting sliced to pieces. The Reborn and the Dark Jedi are able to perform rapid and intricate slash maneuvers that you just cannot.Speaking of frustrating, this game has some of the worst level design I've ever seen. I don't like it when games insist on holding my hand the whole time with large waypoint markers on linear maps but Jedi Outcast really went all the way in the other direction. Almost every mission found me stuck at some point because I simply couldn't figure out where to go next. Sometimes the place you're supposed to go next would turn out to be a tiny grate IN THE CEILING in a non-descript room that you'd already passed through earlier in the level. Sometimes it's an inconspicuous hole that's off to the side of the path, but the path continues for several more encounters with no indication so you wind up fighting through one or two more entire map sections before finally ending up in a place with walls you can't climb and doors that don't open, wondering if there's a switch that you missed somewhere.Ending this on a high note, the plot was good and the sounds of the Star Wars universe are always a pleasure to listen to. The music, the beeps and whirs of panels, even the sound of blaster fire, it's great.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												I have not played with many Star Wars games throughout my "gamer career" but what I do remember is the fond memories I have attached to Jedi Outcast. I believe it is supposed to be a sequel to Jedi Knight 1 which is the sequel to Dark Forces 1... all FPS games and very old now and completely missed out by myself.In any case, Outcast is a blend of FPS and TPS genres. Both perspectives are available throughout the game and they determine the weaponry used to dispose of your enemies. Obviously, weapons such as blasters are for the FPS perspective while wielding your lightsaber is the easiest from a third person perspective.The game has an excellent story and some recognisable faces appear here and there (strictly following the storyline of the trilogy from the '70s / '80s). Music is, of course, the good-old John Williams-composed score and since they are really good why would we need anything else?The only issue with the game is that I remember playing it in FPS mode, at first, but once I obtained the lightsaber I finished the rest in TPS mode. I mean, if having a lightsaber is de rigueur in a Star Wars game then why would you want to switch back to the general assortment of weapons? Also, your lightsaber coupled with the many jedi powers available is the best way to play such a game.The game can be difficult at times but allowing you to follow both paths (i.e. Light and Dark sides) it deserves a second walkthrough. Outcast runs on the Quake 3 engine which, years ago, was quite beautiful but now is somewhat of an obsolete engine. In any case, this is an all-time classic and you are to purchase it especially if you played it already 10 years ago. Collecting classics is always a good pastime!PS: Widescreen resolutions are unavailable from the game menu - head over to wsgf.org to see the solution for the issue.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
												Having put over 75 hours into this game, it's about time i reviewed it.  Don't expect much from me though, as i've never reviewed anything before.Firstly, it's big, and it's beautiful.  Yes, the graphics are dated, and can't compete at all in regards to most games nowadays, but, if like me, you regard graphics secondary to gameplay, then you wont be the least bit disappointed, because they still look great.  At the risk of sounding sacreligious; i'm not that big of a Star Wars fan, so if you aren't either, don't worry...the way this game is executed, even if it had no Star Wars Related themes, it would still tower over many other Action / FPS games.To sum it up: Great dialogue throughout; keeping the story moving, interesting, and consistent.So much to do, so so much!  It's not the most challenging game out there, but there's barely any 'grinding'...the pace remains throughout, and some of the challenges will force you to engage your mind more than you would expect.But most importantly!  It's fun, and interesting.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2016
THE PLOTSTAR WARS™ Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast once again puts you in control of the famous Kyle Katarn, a former Jedi who now operates as a mercenary for the New Republic together with Jan Ors, a female pilot.The game takes place after the events of Jedi Knight: Dark Forces II, but before the events of Jedi Knight: Mysteries of the Sith.At the start of the game, Kyle & Jan have to investigate some leads to the presence of the Imperial Remnant on a supposedly abandoned Imperial outpost on the planet Kejim.They later find out that the Imperials are trying to find the Valley of the Jedi, and use its powers for themselves.Kyle progressively realises that without his Jedi powers, he is unable to protect the ones that he loves.Along Kyle's journey, he meets a variety of legendary Star Wars characters like Luke Skywalker & Lando Calrissian, but you also meet some new enemies like the Dark Jedi Desann.Besides this, Kyle also visits iconic places like Bespin (Cloud City) & Yavin IV.THE GAMEPLAYThis installment of the Jedi Knight series no longer features the RPG-like system that the previous games possesed (the ability to distribute points for certain force powers).This time around the game just gives you certain force abilities overtime, which gradually upgrade as you progress in the story.Most of these force powers however are very well done, and they add a lot of diversity to your combat and play style.A handfull of levels require you to use your newly learned powers to overcome its puzzles.The game also features a wide array of weapons and items that allow you to develop your own playstyle.The only significant problem that I have with the combat, are the hitboxes.In my opinion, the hitboxes are way too small, and often times it is very hard to hit an enemy, even when they are standing still or crouching down right in front of you, let alone an enemy that is running at or away from you.Lastly, I believe that the game has a very decent overall length, and depending on the difficulty that you play on, the game will take you over 10 hours to complete, which is around the same length as the other Jedi Knight games (in my case).THE TECHNICAL ASPECTSThe game ran very smoothly on my end, with a stable 60 fps and no crashes or freezes.The only technical downside of this game is the resolution.The game does not allow fullscreen playing on modern systems, and some of the preset resolutions do not work, but with a few workarounds, this is easily fixed.The game also features a very neat quick save and quick load system, which allows you to save at any point in the game, and load that save whenever you like at the press of a single button.The controls are highly customizable and the standard preset works very well in my opinion.MY VERDICT All in all, Jedi Outcast is one of those overlooked Star Wars games that is actually really good and enjoyable, and it is definitely a significant (technical) improvement over the previous games in the Jedi Knight series.If you are a fan of the Jedi Knight series, or just a fan of good shooters set in the Star Wars universe, then you should definitely give this hidden gem a go!

number of helpful: 17 of 19 people (89%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												I got a ton of Star Wars related games at the Winter Steam Sale, and oh boy I was glad this one was one of them. Now, I'll do my best so my love for this game doesn't hide it's problems, and I will start right off with them, as usual:The biggest problem this game has, is that it was NOT build for computers of this generation. The resolution is not the only problem you'll have to face, but there are also glitches, such as strange shadows and even (at least on my case), strange brightness errors, as I everthing was strangely bright and I had to lower it, making me see it right, but all screenshots show the game to be really dark. If you want to play the game, have patience and look for guides arround the Internet on how to get over these problems.The second problem it has, and really the only other I have, are the difficulty spikes. There are areas of the game that don't f#ck arround. Take Nar Shadda (did I type that right?) as an example, a huge map FILLED WITH SNIPERS, which can easily 1-Hit kill you with barely any time to react... And yet you're supposed to do all kinds of platforming arround it, on which missing a platform will kill you. There are other examples, such as your first encounter with the shadow sith jedi guys, which are WAY MORE POWERFUL AND TOUGH than any other Reborn you've faced so far (even more than the boss before that), and you're supposed to take on two at the same time. Even with all of your powers later on, just one of these guys might get tricky, just get the idea. The game ain't a walk in the park, and you should expect it to be a tough journey.However, is the game good if we look away from those two problems? You bet your motherf#cking♥♥♥♥♥ The game is a sequel on the Jedi Knight series of games, and follows up Kyle Katarn's adventures, but it ain't really needed that you play the previous games to understand it. However, you might need a bit of knowledge about Star Wars to understand most of it. It starts as a classic FPS with tons of enemies, no regenerative health, armor (or shields, in this case), and a ton of enemies who are pathetic and weak in comparison with you. However, the game changes itself mid-way, as soon enough you have a light-saber and can use the power of the force, AND THAT'S WHEN THE GAME TRULY GOES FROM GOOD TO F#CKING GREAT. Light-saber combat on this game is insanely fun to pull-off, specially against other Light-saber users.The force also feels natural on the game, neither being useless or broken: just like in the movies, it's a tool. You can push stuff, pull stuff, slow-down the game, mind-trick people like old Ben Kenobi did on the movies, a ton of cool stuff. There are a lot of powers in the game, and you unlock them as you go through it. Some enemies also use them, and eventually you'll find a use to most of them on your play-style.The story and the characters also feel great. I won't spoil much more (I did spoil that you get a light-saber, BUT COME ON, KYLE HAS IT ON NEARLY ALL THE ADDS OF THE GAME ANYWAY!), but the only thing I didn't like about them is that Lando doesn't appear nearly enough, and characters such as Han Solo would have also been great. Oh, and the game goes after Episode VI and before the new one.The multiplayer was fun, also. And I say "was" and not "is", as I doubt there are many servers, anymore. If you want the game for the multiplayer, look for Jedi Academy instead, it's sequel. But if you want a really GOOD and solid singleplayer experience, look no further. This game on a sale is quite the steal, and if you like Star Wars, you're garanteed to like it. And if you don't... Well, refund the game, seek medical attention.

Posted: May 24, 2015
PROS:+ good story+ great gameplay+ lightsaber combat+ cool missions+ Kyle Katarn+ good modsCONS:- graphic & resolution options are outdated- sometimes clunky lightsaber combat- multiplayer is less visited (try Jedi Academy instead)- sometimes confusing level designComment:We again get to play as Kyle Katarn a jedi who does not really want to be one. The game is much more blaster/mine/rocket oriented at first, later the lightsaber comes into play too. While good the lightsaber animations could have used a bit polish as they are clunky sometimes. But they are still fun. ... a lot of fun! With the dismemberment option on it feels like really having a powerful weapon you can cut every opponent with. And again we also get Force powers. The level design is done the classic Jedi Knight way - sometimes good and sometimes confusing. But the game remains enjoyable. The community of players who play online is weaker compared to Jedi Academy so I advise trying that out for MP. The mods are there for this game and use most of the potential so maybe take a look at some. This is a fine game for all who like Star Wars and/or have played the previous Jedi Knight games. I recommend it!

content:
Posted: July 8, 2013
												When comparing Jedi Outcast to fellow contemporary titles. There has yet to be a game that blends design and functionality to such a startling degree.You follow Kyle Katarn, returned to a jaded mercenary after the events of the last game. After a few routine levels you are immediately thrust onto a revenge odyssey across the galaxy. Going from isolated outposts in the middle of nowhere, to Cloud City, to the sprawling nest of Nar Shadda. The game keeps a good pace and it has an extraordinary lightsaber combat system.That's nothing to say about the multiplayer and the modding community this game had, at it's height it was immensly popular and customizeable. You could play this game however you wanted, and with a great community of players.The only other real contender Outcast has for greatest Star Wars game is most likely it's sequel Jedi Academy.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2016
A great star wars jedi experience marred by dodgy platforming, occasionally poor level design and infuriating difficulty spikes. Jedi Outcast puts the player into the shoes of Kyle Katarn who, at the beginning of the game is force-less. Meaning you have a couple of levels of rather typical FPS (though the levels are more maze-like than linear. Then you get your force powers back, your lightsaber is returned to you and you're good to go.That is if it didn't then put you into a level where those force powers are completely redundant. Sure, I just got my lightsaber, I want to do some chopping, not get insta-shot by distant hidden snipers in a city scape, or pummeled by grenade throwing annoyances from above me. The first couple of levels on their own are good, if a little frustrating at times because of the almost puzzle-like design of them. You'll find yourself wondereding what you need to do to progress. The levels themselves are very very long indeed with only scattered checkpoints, and sparcely scattered at that. You'll be using the Quick Save function a Lot, believe me. This is good because it gives you, and the game a chance to craft some really interesting levels and locales, but as I say on the other hand, saves are a must, and sometimes you will be scratching your head if you have missed the smallest thing which is necessary to move on. Over the course of the game your force powers increase gradually such that at the beginning of your force use your jump is little more than a Yoshi flutter-kick, but by the end of the game you are flying over 12x your original jump height. It's quite a marked change, but given the gradual nature you do feel as though you are developing through the course of the game. Challenges are varied as well which comes together by the end of the game making you feel accomplished. The story itself is good enough, it's good to not have something focused on the skywalkers. The story is uncovered over time as you are something of an investigator, which also plays to the game's strengths. The ending kind of happens though and is a little lack lustre, but then I'd recommend going and playing the sequel - Jedi Academy, wholeheartedly. A fantastic game in my opinion and solves a number of issues that arose with Outcast.The other frustrations are of the boss battles which are another of those difficulty spikes which are just stupid and rage-inducing.I am not reviewing multiplayer here, but if it is anything like Jedi Academy (which I hear it is) then it's arguably the best star wars multiplayer available (in combination with Academy).

content:
Posted: June 6, 2016
Star wars - Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast			* 9/10Definitely one of My favourite games, and my favourite Jedi Knight Chapter.Jedi Knight 2 is the following chapter and takes place about two years after Mysteries of The Sith. Kyle abandoned both the force and his lightsaber after the incident at the end of the MotS and now works with Jan Ors on some missions for the Republic. Mon Mothma, Leader of the New Republic, sent them to a remnant base because of an intercepted communication citing the valley of the jedi and a rebirth. They will discover some experiments, and after an ambush Kyle will be forced to re-establish his connection with the force and get back his lightsaber in order to retaliate against the remnants.I know it might sound dull but I'm trying to keep the most important details because I would spoil the best parts of the story, which is very important in this chapter, as it's very well studied. And during our journey we'll meet very well known character as Lando And Luke Dubbed by Billy Dee Williams and Mark Hamill Themselves.The gameplay follows the classic structure of the previous chapters but it's more polished and has lots of innovations that make this chapter the best. You start the game without lightsaber or force powers as in Dark Forces 2, so you will use blasters and weapons. There will be some old classics, such as Kyle's blaster pistol, the wookie bowcasters, thermal detonators, and the good old the E-11 blaster rifle that will be imprecise as usual (in a shy attempt to justify the stormtroopers' lame aim). Of course there will be new weapons, as rocket launchers, explosives and tripbombs, but the real innovation comes as soon as you recover your force powers and your lightsaber as a third person view is applied and the levels will urge you to jump up and down with your jedi powers. Now jump and the saber throw are not force powers to use but are implicit in your actions (meaning you can use force jump as you jump, and launch the lightsaber with the secondary fire button), and the best part is of course the lightsaber combat system. Now you don't have just a couple of clunky moves, now you have a proper combat system where your moves will be determined by any direction key you use and you will "learn" three combat styles, Normal, Strong and fast that will allow to deal different damage ranges, strike with different speeds and chain your moves also with coreographics rotations. During your fights you can also lock you lightsaber against a sith's lightsaber and you have to hit fire as fast as you can to push harder and leave the opponent defenseless for a few second so you can exploit that opening to strike hard.Anyways this is the only Jedi knight you don't choose light or dark side, as the story requires a fixed path and the force powers are improved automatically as the level design might require specific powers and abilities.One of my favorite aspects of this game is music. I definitely Love the Star Wars tunes from John Williams and in this chapter there are great classic tunes and, as opposed to Dark Forces 2 and MotS we have again dynamic music, with quiet and action tunes perfectly linked with smooth passage tunes. Something already seen (or maybe  heard) already with the first Dark Forces Midi tracks and now back again in great style and high quality.Another really great side of this game is the visual impact. Even nowadays the levels are really good looking and the Star Wars atmosphere is stronger than ever, since the very beginning. But as I said, the best comes the moment you get your lightsaber with the force powers: the first mission will be in Nar Shaddaa, the vertical city, then Bespin City and so on. There will be lots of familiar ambients, neverending pits, gigantic vertical structures that only a Jedi will ever be able to walk through.The engine is based on id Tech 3 (Quake 3 Arena's Engine), And even though it's not the new battlefront Engine, it doesn't look bad, all in all. Level design is really good and saves this title from aging really bad, even though the polygon counter for maps and models doesn't even compare recent titles and volumetric shadows on characters really look bad, buggy and odd, while all the other FXs really give great justice to the game.At the time the Ghoul system was the thing so it was mandatory: every character or NPC has "Hot spots" which will determine a specific pain or death animation.Unfortunately there are some cons, which didn't stop me from playing and appreciate to the fullest this game, anyways.The game doesn't support 16:9 resolutions natively... But you can edit with notepad the config file to force your desired resolution and fix the FOV in order to keep an appropriate perspective.As long as you move in First person you won't notice that too much but as soon as you switch in third person it's more evident. At the time I couldn't stand it so I decided to make my ow mod for them: animations are a bit rigid and clunky. Your idle positions are improbable as the character doesn't even try to breath, you and everyone else walk and run as if you were slipping because the animation is too slow to represent the speed you're moving at.And the worst part of the game: AI. Yes, siths are strong and both stormtroopers and mercenaries will shoot you or run for safer places according to your position or they will just run away and surrender in case you pull away their weapon, but it won't be rare to face enemies that won't recognize you or the mess and killing you made 10 mts away, or enemies that will run back and forth not knowing what to do, or falling down in pits. +++PROs+++ STORY. Clearly I loved this chapter's story, Kyle gets back his force powers with a better and more logical reason here than in DF2 (where he spontaneously becomes a Jedi without any training). We have everything in this story: a plot, a reason for revenge, hope and redemption, tributes (lots of guests, places, references, and a particular boss fight that somehow reminds me of the final fighth in Dark Forces) and... KYLE KATARN. The very best portrayal of this character, someone that has seen lots of things in the universe, did many good and bad things and his sarcasm proves he aged knowing that. Kyle know he's not perfect, he's not a saint and knows he's not a Jedi, but he's "just a guy with a lightsaber" that will do his very best to achieve his goals, be it stop the remnants or mere revenge. SOUNDTRACK. I love so much John William's music and the re-introduction of the dynamic music system in this chapter is really great and delivers an amazing soundtrack that perfectly fits and follows your actions, be it explorations or fights. Simply great. VISUAL IMPACT. The game is getting old but it still looks pretty good thanks to a very good level design and familiar places. GAMEPLAY. It's simply amazing to fight with such a good system, I've always loved the lightsaber fights as that's still my favourite most used weapon, and force powers are much more comfortable to use than the previous chapter. You can also run and jump on walls, which is useless but really coreagraphic.---CONs--- AI. You will face enemies that won't recognize you or the mess and killing you made 10 mts away, or enemies that will run back and forth not knowing what to do, or falling down in pits. 4:3. Unfortunately, due to the age, the game doesn't support 16:9 resolutions natively. Luckily you can just edit the cfg to force your own resolution. Everything is explained in details in the steam community. CLUNKY ANIMATIONS. There are some clunky or too basic animations in the game such as "non-breathing" idle positions or slow running and walking animations.

content:
Posted: January 5
												Ah, Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast. I have fond memories of this game from when it was first released. I was entering my teen years and I remember playing the demo of this game at my local Best Buy. I remember how floored I was at how awesome the gunplay, lightsaber and Force mechanics were. It made me eager to play the full version. While I wasn't able to play the PC version of it, I eventually was able to play it on my old Xbox.Now, full disclosure, back then, I was quite the cheating little ****. If the game had cheats for it, more often than not, I would use them. I had no interest in being challenged, and I didn't want to lose, ever. So it was the same with this game. Despite my cheating ways, however, I remember having a ton of fun with the game. The lightsaber and Force mechanics were amazing, and it had a great story to go with it.A decade and a half later, I, now older, wiser, and more willing to challenge myself when it comes to video games, come across it being offered here on Steam, and nostalgically, I decided to purchase it and give it another whirl, without cheats this time. Play it as it was meant to be played.However, within a couple hours of playing, I found myself coming to a stark, unanimous realization: This game is one tough son of a *****, especially the first couple of levels before you get the lightsaber and Force powers and all you have to rely on are blasters to kill enemies who maddeningly never seem to stop moving for long enough for you to get a bead on them, and there are often several of them at a time, and they tend to swarm you and shoot at you from multiple angles. If you get into a huge firefight, you have to constantly be on the move to avoid the hail of gunfire coming at you, while at the same time straining to target your enemies who, like I said, are also moving around constantly. And God help you if there are any officer-type enemies among them, or ones firing rapid shot blasters. You will end up dying quite a lot on these first two levels, I guarantee it. And I was playing on medium difficulty! Oh, and also, the checkpoint system in this game is atrocious, so you'd better make sure to manually save your game a lot, or you will find yourself losing a ton of progress when you inevitably die.Once you get the lightsaber and access to the Force powers, though, the pressure eases up a bit, as you're able to deflect all the annoying blaster fire, and you'll eventually get the Heal Force power to let you regain heath. But you'll still have to watch to make sure enemies are not flanking you from behind when using your lightsaber. And there's the all new challenge of lightsaber duels. There's a whole lot of strategy involved in lightsaber dueling; you will die quickly if you're not careful in engaging your opponent. Despite the tough difficulty curve, and the admittedly outdated graphics, I still find Jedi Outcast (and its sequel, Jedi Academy, for that matter) a really good game. The lightsaber and Force mechanics in this game still have no equal compared to other Star Wars games, in my opinion. They are just as fun and thrilling to use now as when I first played it. The story is also very good. And hey, you get to play as Kyle Katarn, the legendary bearded badass himself. If you're looking for a great Star Wars game and do not mind a tough challenge, then I heartily recommend you check out Jedi Outcast.

												Ever wanted a game that made you feel like you are a Jedi, complete with all the amazing force powers? Then look no further than Jedi Knight 2. The lightsaber combat is amazing (even allowing in-game cheats that make all lightsabers realistic to the movies), you have some amazing force powers at your disposal (Grip, Lightning, Mind Trick), and the game is just fun to play (looking at you, Force Unleashed!). The game also supports a multiplayer that is still very active, and also has AI bots for those who don't want to play with others. In conclusion, if you want a fun Star Wars game (made by the same people who made the X-Men: Origins Wolverine game) Jedi Knight 2 is the game for you.

												Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast came out in 2002 and it's still a worthy title to play today. Although Jedi Outcast is older and pretty similar like Jedi Academy, I like this game a bit more.+ You play as Kyle Katarn. content:
Posted: March 17
Star Wars: Jedi Knight II- Jedi Outcast is pretty cool, I guess.  You play as Kyle Katarn, a name that carries as much weight in the legacy universe of Star Wars as Luke Skywalker or Han Solo or Gartogg. Sent out to investigate the Imperial Remnants of several planets, Kyle, and his partner, Jan, get caught up in a plan by the Remnants that leads to pain, adventure, mystery, and cool lightsaber fights.Jedi Outcast came out in 2002 when it was hip to make everything on the Quake III engine. And when it came out it looked really good. It still does, though you need to fiddle with the options just to not make it look all wonky on your new intergalactic space computer. As Kyle, the coolest guy with the lamest name, you get a variety of weapons. Outside of the lightsaber that even the original game box advertised back in the day, you also get blasters, bowcasters, rocket launchers, space shotguns, space sniper rifles, thermo detonators, trip mines, and even that little orb thing that shot look in the original movie. The shooting is nice, all of the blasters have the iconic Star Wars sound effects. They're crunchy, fun to fire, and since most of them have a delay like before hitting their target like a blaster in Star Wars would, you usually have to predict where your opponent is going to move before you fire.While the shooting is fun, the lightsaber begins to take center stage as your powers grow and you become one of those intergalactic murder hobos known as a Jeddy. Not only can you murder fools with the space knife but you can also block incoming attacks and throw it like a very dangerous boomerang. Like the one from Road Warrior but not thrown by that kid with autism. There's a big power trip in just clearing a room with your blue stick, dodging or deflecting incoming blasters, throwing people around with force powers, and leaping over fools before cutting them down. The levels in single player are impressively large. Each area is unique considering most places you go to are in different parts of the galaxy from the last. “Abandoned” outposts, mining facilities, crime city, and Lando's crib are places you will visit on your journey to hit people with your laser sword. “That's fine and all.” You tell me as you kick me in the junk. “But tell me about the really cool stuff.” That was very rude of you.Well if a really tight first person shooter with cool third person combat and sword fighting doesn't appeal to you then check this out. Jedi Outcast was released at a time when Modding was at a all time high. I remember about a year after it's release someone made a total conversion mod that was a single level where you play as a Gladiator in Rome. Not only was it kind of neat, but it was actually pretty educational as well.Not only that, but there are skin packs, like one that returns Kyle to his original appearance in Dark Forces that was released in 1995. Fan made gameplay tweaks exist as well. If that doesn't tickle your pickle then there are also an assortment of console commands that can add replay value or just flat out break your game.One console command that stands out actually increases dismemberment from your lightsaber swings, adding things such as cutting off heads or flat out bisecting people depending on high you set the value. I feel like the original idea was to always be able to dismember people, but maybe Lucas Arts didn't allow anything other than hands or arms? I don't know, I don't actually have any info on that.But how friggin cool is that? You just type out a console command, slap in a few numbers, and suddenly you have the most brutal Star Wars game ever made. So what else is there to cover? Multiplayer, duh. Pay attention.So I went into multiplayer with the intent of screwing around with some bots and covering the game modes. But to my surprise I actually found a few people still playing? Back when I first played in 2004, I went into multiplayer ready to smash heads and immediately found a bunch of people just kind of standing around and chatting while other people fought in makeshift arenas around the map.There were a handful of servers that focused on deathmatch, team deathmatch, etc, but a good majority of them were about dueling. Jedi Outcast's lightsaber combat, which was mostly about positioning, movement, and timing, was just complex enough to gather a cult following for dueling. I remember challenging someone to a duel, then bowing before the fight begins, predating a certain other games dueling community by a few years. But back then it was fun to just sometimes sit around and chat with others, or jump and flip around the map. There were clan wars that would break out on servers, rivalries that got pretty intense at some points. Jedi Outcast's multiplayer back in the day was something special, and finding it so empty actually made me feel...Sad, I guess. I got a chance to talk to the 5 or so people that were actually playing at the time, with one person saying that he has been playing since 2004. I didn't stay around to duel, but I did ask a few questions.They said it was weird to be part of a such a super niche community, remnants of what was a rather large nation back in the day. But the dedication of who was left was something to admire.It's sad to see the multiplayer the way it is now. The last members of the Jedi Outcast community are an endangered species of true fans, even if there's only a few of them left. But hey, Jedi Outcast had it's run, it had a few years of fame and countless hours of good memories between thousands of players. And all good things have to come to an end, right?  Should you play Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast? The single player still holds up, coming out at a time before Disney decided to throw away thousands of stories in the galaxy far far away. The combat and exploration are still fun, even though you may get so lost in the early levels that you may as well set up camp and play campfire songs.  But Jedi Outcast's multiplayer was one of it's big draws in the early 00s. It was special and stood out from many of the other games that were out at the time. But hey, I know a lot of you still have Jedi Outcast sitting around, either in a jewel case or on your Steam library. It's never going to revive, I'm not that optimistic. But if you ever feel like just reinstalling, if just for a little bit, maybe stop by one of the servers and say hi to who's left, maybe stop for a duel or two. While you still can. Star Wars: Jedi Knight II- Jedi Outcast gets a score of 9 in a galaxy far far away out of 10. Oh man, that last part really bummed me out. The Curator: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Dickbuttexperience#curation

content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
												This is one of the best Star Wars games. I've played it through again just few weeks ago so my opinion is not based on nostalgia. While Jedi Academy adds lightsaber moves and is newer this one has better story (not anything amazing but it mostly makes sense and that's more than what I can say about most recent games) and makes you appreciate weapons other than the lightsaber. The puzzles are a mixed bag, most are good but there are some that will make you run in circles (although usually you just need to look up to solve them). Jedi Outcast's strongest point is undoubtedly combat - a mix of classic FPS and great lightsaber/force system. Some powers/weapons are obviously better than the others but on Padawan difficulty level you can pretty much play around as you like. And play around you can! Force Pull stormtrooper's rifle from his hands and watch as he runs away in panic! Grab one enemy with Force Choke and shield yourself from his friends fire! Finally, I recommend playing with a certain cheat code activated - g_saberRealisticCombat 1 - It allows you to cut apart enemies a lot more than the base game (although it's a bit buggy and results in beheaded characters screaming and other weirdness. Nothing gamebreaking though). Word of warning - it makes the game both easier and harder since it makes some hit zones an instant kill (for both player and npcs). It causes shorter, more frantic duels with Dark Jedi and can end the final battle in seconds (which is hilarious when it happens). Overall I rate the game 8.5/10 (-1,5 for all the annoyances along the way). It's not a perfect game but still loads of fun and worth it's price.

STAR WARS™ Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast™ 
A Screenshot of STAR WARS™ Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast™
By: Devonian_AUS




Disclaimer: I am a huge Star Wars fan, and have played this game a lot as a child/teenager, so as my foot note points out (see the bottom of my review pages), this review may be biased.Title Information  Review Title Star Wars Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast   Review Date 10th of March 2016   PC Release Date 26th of March 2002   Developer Raven Software   Publisher LucasArts   Genre 1st & 3rd Person Shooter/Action Adventure   Series Dark Forces (3rd in the Series)   Single Player Yes   Multiplayer Yes  Ratings  Category Score   Story 8/10   Single Player Gameplay 9/10   Multiplayer Gameplay 9/10   Graphics & Art Style 9/10   Replayability 7/10   Overal Rating 9/10 (See bottom of the page for ranking descriptions)Devo's Seal of Approval?:Totally! I am signing, sealing, and delivering this title to you as a must play. This entry in the Dark Forces Series takes the mantle from its predecessors and makes it 10 feet taller. This title makes me yearn for a modern, force user centric 1st person shooter set in the Star Wars universe - a yearning which was not quite quenched with the re-release of Battlefront in 2015.PROS The solid and ground breaking gameplay from Dark Forces & Dark Forces II is back, Streamlined user interface which is easy to navigate, Amazing lightsaber combat with subtle, yet strong features including stance variation, Improved character movement including acrobatic features, Familiar and iconic enemies with interesting new additions, Excellent new weapons, Addition of a slow-motion action- and death-sequence camera, Great graphics with amazing attention to detail (rain drops hitting your lightsaber make it "sizzle"!), Iconic locations influenced by the original titles in the series, and the original Star Wars Trilogy, Well implemented inclusions of iconic characters such as Luke Skywalker & Lando Calrissian,CONS A lack of the previously implemented psuedo-RPG system, Occasionally glitchy hit recognition,CONCLUSIONS...A great 1st person shooter and an outstanding Star Wars game. This title takes you on a magnificanet and exciting return journey; not only into Star Wars, but into the Dark Forces mythos and the Expanded Universe (now labelled Star Wars "Legends"). 


STAR WARS™ Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast™ 
A Screenshot of STAR WARS™ Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast™
By: Devonian_AUS




While at the time of writing this review this title was almost 15 years old, it has aged incredibly well. The attention to detail Raven Software managed to pack into this game is amazing, with the rain even "sizzling" against the blade of your lightsaber on some levels. The atmoshpere, the gameplay, the difficulty challenge, the level design, the story, the character monouverability...the amount of content - all should be used as a standard against which to measure even today's AAA blockbusters.


STAR WARS™ Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast™ 
A Screenshot of STAR WARS™ Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast™
By: Devonian_AUS




As with any title. there are some flaws with the game, however, these are all really minor and are a sign of its age. The only truly negative aspect, which is still only a minor detraction from the overall experience, was the removal of the pseudo-RPG system introduced in Dark Forces II. I missed the opportunity to specialise my character in either the light or dark side of the force, which seemed to add another variation to the gameplay and to the replayability of Dark Forces II. This is easy to forgive however, and does make old Kyle Katarn a little more versatile; quickly dispatching foes with force grip, while still having the ability to heal yourself with the force.All in all this game is amazing; even by today's standards. Stop reading this review right now and go and buy this title... better yet, buy the Dark Forces Bundle - YOU WON'T REGRET IT!._______________________RANKING DESCRIPTIONS  Score Description   1 This pile of c%$p made me want to take a break from gaming!   2 Avoid this title like a fat man on a diet avoids cake.   3 Why did they even bother? Oh wait...they didn't, so niether should you.   4 I wouldn't play this unless I was really, really desperate, or the biggest fan alive.   5 While there are some interesting aspects of this title, there are just too many faults to recommend it to anyone.   6 An "average" title which has some redeeming qualities, however, be warned that it also has its fair share of flaws...   7 A good game and it probably shouldn't be missed by fans of the series or genre, but be warned there are better games out there which are more deserving of your time and money.   8 An excellent title which shouldn't be missed if you can help it. I found it hard to put this game down, and I hope you do too.   9 A master piece! As close to perfect as any title can get. You are truly missing out on an unbelievable gaming experience if you do not play this game.   10 PERFECT. Nothing more needs to be said All ratings and opinions expressed in this review are subjective, and therefore are effected in part by my own preferences & predisposiitons. I have not received any gifts or gratuities froma any party for this work.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2016
												Probably one of the only games i'll ever write a review for but being a diehard Star Wars fan i just have to. So if you are a Star Wars fan searching for a really good game this is the one for you. Sure you'll have to glare over the not as BF1 pretty 2003 graphics but the combat system, story and even the difficulty is well worth it. I for one like a little bit of realism especially when it comes to Star Wars. (pls don't kill me for this but that's why i really like the scene in the phantom menance where Qui-Gon Jin cuts open the door) Which is totally possible in this game with a little bit of autoexec fiddling. Put your lightsaber on cut everthing mode and it finally feels satisfying when you finally slice your way through one of the enemey's shadow troopers or shadow adepts. So to talk about some of the different aspects of the game.The prize: If you cant find those 10 Bucks just get it on a sale. I grabbed it for 2€ and got 16 hours of gameplay out of the story alone. Which also leads me to my next point.The Gameplay & Difficulty: What really amazed me about this game is that i didnt get bored. New games tend to loose my attention after like 1 1/2 hour but this one just grabbed me and pinned me to my seat ... for hours. Reason for this is that the difficulty is getting procedurely harder as you are getting better and more used to the game. I don't even know how often i reloaded my save after a lousy shadow adept ripped my head of, electrified my corpse and send my remains straight down a cliff. Added to that there is some thinking involved in almost all of the levels aswell which made me actually feel dumb after finally finding an exit or something comparable after 10 minutes of searching and consulting a walkthrough. So if you are looking for a challenge too, this is your game. Story: Talking about story in the Star Wars franchise which isn't directly related to any of the movies was and is always a dangerous path with Star Wars fans. Take Star Wars: The Force Unleashed, whilst the first game is considered to have a good story but Starkiller being really overpowered, you have the second installment of the game which really lacked in quality causing Disney to pull not only the production but also the canon-plug. What i want to say is that it is really hard to create a good Star Wars story an this game certainly nailed it. You get to meet characters you know and love as it plays some time after the sixth movie. Looking at the plot retroactively you could even think that it is all canon even with the seventh movie already being out. Even though i don't know if it actually is still considered canon. Now you're probably asking yourself how well does it run?System Compatibilty: Which is actually pretty interesting. Since the Jedi Knight II is on Steam you threrefore shouldn't have any sytem issues but there a some things that need a manual fixing. The game comes with some wonky unusual resolution settings that noone uses anymore but you i guess we have to cut the game some slack since as i said earlier it came out in 2003. These can be adjusted through a autoexec file which can easily be created and packed with commands. On my machine the game gives my PC a spastic shock when i try to minimize it fullscreen but that could be only my issue. I hope atleast one of you sat through my whole review and decides to give this amazing game a try after reading through that mess of fandom babbling. Wish you the best time playing and ..... Force ...... you!

content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												A classic, is amongst my favorite games. The game has amazing lightsaber combat, some of the best sword style combat on any platform. Jedi Outcast has great shooting mechanics as well as easy access Force powers.Being the game came out in 2003, it takes influence from many sources. It contains elements of influence from the matrix, force jump allows you to run up walls, and force speed slows all projectiles around you. The game even has the unreal Flak Cannon (called the flechette gun). The game has an interesting online community with more than just your standard death match fare. It has a different rule set with players often taking time to duel rather than straight openly murder each other (Though some servers have different rules and contain straight death match) It's worth taking note you can turn off your lightsaber with the 1 button, often players find the saber turned state as you being hostile.For the cheap price of 10 bucks this game is worth it, I've spent easily over 400 hours on it. (Not the steam version but when I owned the disc)

												I remember playing this game a kid. When I saw this game on steam by chance, I couldn't believe it at first because I figured you couldnt buy games this old anymore. I would basically fly around the maps and just grab stormtroopers and throw them off a cliff or something haha. All joking aside about my childhood, this game is so fun and for only 10 dollars it is a steal. Just buy it. Be warned though because the game seems deceptively easy at first, but there are probably hundreds of instant death zones in the game. Play through on padawan first to get a feel for the controls as there is a learning curve (can you imagine a game this old still has a learning curve? a testament to its greatness), and then play through on the difficulty of your chosing and become a jedi!.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												12-13 Years later and the Master Servers are still up. There's still multiplayer servers for this game. And still one of the best online communities I've ever experienced. Mods is what made this game too. Just sucks websites like JK2Files.com is shut down. Only game that ive played where you have Jedi Master Kyle Katarn vs Blade (Marvel) vs Sephiroth (FF7) vs Spongebob in a Free For All. Damn I missed this game.--The Dark Forces series in general is amazing, especially Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast & Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy.I spent a lot of time in multiplayer in my Clan's servers. We had Clan vs Clan matches, invasions, plus all the mods, skins and maps that came out for that game. So much user created content which really helped that game in the long run. People made maps from movies like Matrix to the famous "Duel of the Fates" scene (Darth Maul vs Qui-Gon Jinn & Obi-Wan Kenobi). Imagine playing as Blade (Wesley Snipes) with a lightsaber or even Sephiroth from FFVII. Thousands of options to chose from, thanks to "jk2files.com" and the community they helped build.Plus the community was one of the most respectful gaming communities I've ever been apart of.In 1v1 Lightsaber duels, people wished each other "Good Luck" and bowed before a duel, then said "Good Fight" after a duel had ended. Regardless of a win or loss.Looking forward to another Jedi Knight series multiplayer, mainly to bring back that nostalgia. Definitely one of my favorite Star Wars Franchise Games ever made.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												To begin with: I recommend you to buy this game, it's more then worth it.Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast is a game in the series of Dark Forces and Jedi Knight. In my opinion it is the best game in the whole series (some may disagree) because it contains a very nice single player and and very good (and well balanced) multiplayer.Singeplayer: The SP is set after the collapse of the empire. The ex-Jedi Knight Kyle Katarn is working as a mercenary for the new formed republic, trying to find outposts of the Remnant troops of the empire, who still work against the republic. In the process of the singleplayer Katarn regains his jedi power and discovers the real aims of the imperial troops. The story telling is very well embeded in the normal game flow, which is a good mix of action (fighting with weapons, lightsabers, force) and thinking (solving puzzles, finding ways). There is an option to set the level of difficulty, so the game is demanding, no matter how good or bad you are.Multiplayer: After the SP (which is quite long), you may want to play MP. The general MP is very similiar to other Quake3-Games: You have Gametypes like Deathmatch, TD, CTF etc. But there are also some special gamemodes like JediMaster (one player is the jedimaster with every force power, the rest just owns weapons and has to kill him), CTY (like CTF but the flag-stealer isnt allowed to use force), Holocron (the force powers are spreaded at the maps in little boxes which you can pick up).  After you joined a MP server you'll have to set your name, your skin and your force powers, where you can choose either the dark or light side and disturb force points in the different powers (like lightning, absorbation, healing, jump, speed). Note that there servers which disable weapons or forces, leaving you with nothing more than your saber ;)The MP experience itself is unique - you can have normal deathmatches there, but also nice chats or exciting light saber duels; the lightsaber fight is the best I have ever seen in a Star Wars game: you can choose your style (fast, medium, slow means: less, normal, many damage per hit) and the saber reacts to every mouseclick you do, so with a bit of training you can do really nice combos. Also, back then, the modding community was quite active, giving you access to dozens of very good maps, tools and server mods.Sooo all in all - buy the game, you'll not regret it :Dps: I know Steam shows 0 hours on record, thats because my old JK wasnt linked with steam - my real play time lies anywhere among 500 and 1000 hours.pss: ooh and sorry for my english, this isn't my main language.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2016
												I got started on this series with the original Jedi Knight and at the time I thought that playing as a Jedi could not get any better. I got out of gaming for a while though and missed the XBOX era almost completely (I'm mostly a console gamer. Gross, I know). So it wasn't until much later that I learned there were sequels to Jedi Knight. By the time I realized this, enough time had passed that my measly home computer had enough power to run both this and Jedi Academy on high settings. With the new movie coming out recently and my little boy getting his interest in Star Wars sparked, I got a renewed interest myself. I purchased these sequels and I've had an absolute BLAST revisiting the world of JK. I'm not a fan of Kyle Katarn as a character, so I have a little bit more love for Academy than Outcast, but it's hard to beat either one of them. This game is a great balance of gunplay, lightsaber fighting, and force use that you don't find in many of the Star Wars games out there that let you play as a Jedi. You're not vastly overpowered like in The Force Unleashed and the lightsaber fights feel like actual FIGHTS rather than choreographed duels. Every time you get that slow motion kill animation, it feels like a little victory because you have to employ strategy on even the lowliest of lightsaber wielding enemies in this game.The graphics also hold up very well, with this game maybe even looking a bit better than Academy in my opinion. The sound effects and music are spot on recreations of the movies and it's hard not to get excited every time you hear the ignition, swing, and clash noises from your saber. Basically, to make a long story short, if you're a Star Wars fan and you like action games or games that let you portray a Jedi, it's hard to go wrong visiting the galaxy far, far away with Kyle and Jan.

content:
Posted: February 26
												After disposing of all my old CDs in favour of copies on Steam, I recently bought JK2 and found the game to be just as enjoyable as it was all those years ago. Okay, so naysayers may moan about the graphics not being up to modern standards, but I don’t think that matters – at least not to me, anyway, because hey, it’s Star Wars and the opportunity to leap around the room hacking and slashing with a light-sabre is always going to be fun, no matter how pixelated it may be.Pros:Cheap at twice the price.Great combat action.Great atmosphere that really feels STAR WARS!Good immersion factor.Good light-sabre action compared to JK1.Good selection of weapons, although you rarely use them once you get your hands on a light-sabre.Engaging story.Cons:Too many jumping puzzles.Takes too long to acquire force abilities.No light-sabre for at least a third of the game.Poor cut-scenes compared to JK1 (but that’s budget constraints for you, I guess – hiring real actors and sets can’t be cheap).On balance, JK2 is a good, entertaining game that is challenging as well as fun. If you like Star Wars and fancy your chances with a light-sabre, then this is for you.

Posted: January 23
												JK2, one of my favourite games ever. I think pretty much my entire teenage years were taken up playing this game! An absolutely brilliant single player story of Kyle Katarn getting back his force powers in an effort to be able to battle, and then defeat the evil Desaan. The maps are well made, characters range from ejoyable to kill to extremely enjoyable to kill, and it features some truly excellent levels such as Nar Shaddaa. From force grip to some cheeky mind control, JK2 gives you the ability to enjoy all the force has to offer from both the light and the dark. The active multiplayer may have for the most part gone the way of the dinosaurs, but for a few years in the mid -00s, there was nothing I would rather be doing. Some excellent ctf with a top class and vibrant community. This game is not only nostalgic, but even lives up to my memories and more. I can't count how many times I have played this, but I always love to play it again. Probably my most reccommended game of all time.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2016
												(NO SPOILERS)If you also own the game "Star Wars Jedi Knight - Jedi Academy", don't be confused about the story."Star Wars Jedi Knight II - Jedi Outcast" is actually part 1 instead of part 2.(the stories: Jedi Outcast is part 1, and Jedi Academy is part 2)You will understand more if you play both games, story wise.This game is very good and one of the classic Star Wars games as well.It is unfortunate since Disney owns Star Wars, that Disney removed several stories of games, comics, and books from the Star Wars universe including these games. So it isn't a official story anymore.I recommend this game about its story, as well the game-play. But mostly cause of the story.The remnants of the fallen Galactic Empire remains in the galaxy with new leaders and seeks new opportunities to reach their goals.<<< (Jedi Knight) Story Wise >>>If you would like to follow the whole story from the start to the end, then start & play from:* Dark Forces* Dark Forces II* Mysteries of the Sith* Jedi Knight II - Jedi Outcast* Jedi Knight - Jedi Academy( Steam also offers the Jedi Knight bundle with these games (also no longer official Star Wars stories): http://store.steampowered.com/sub/2103/ )

												I wrote a long and interesting review and messed up pressing "back" inadvertently, so here is the short version:Good game, buy it when it goes on sale. Blasters (and almost every weapon) suck (except a few of the later ones), but you don't give a sith about it (see what I did there?) once you become a Jedi again, given the awesome light-saber combat and force powers that are included.Mediocre shooter (since everything moves faster than most of the projectiles in the game), great Jedi Simulator. This game is still far from stale or dated, except for the stupid level design that took place in a couple of spots in the storyline. I just finished it, and it was completely worth my time and effort to learn how to handle the bloody saber.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												Of all the Jedi Knight games, I thought this one was the best, both story-wise and in terms of gameplay. As a sequel to Jedi Knight, Jedi Outcast continues the tale of Kyle Katarn, a man whose experience with the Dark Side in Mysteries of the Sith has left him rather jaded with regards to the Force. He comes out a better man for it, though – it is in this game that he established himself as one of my favourite Star Wars characters ever.Now, Jedi Knight II is a game from the early 00's, so it's obviously a bit dated. The fact that you are a fan of Star Wars suggests, however, that you should be able to look past that... and if you can, I guarantee that you're in for one heck of a treat.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												Great game- Start off with no, not a lightsaber but a classic E11- Blaster Rifle. The levels are quite puzzling, a challenge for some, breeze for others. Recommend this to Star Wars fans who are up for an adventure. After going through a few puzzling missions, you'll eventually gain force powers and a lightsaber. I'm not going to go any further (spoilers). But the lightsaber battles are great and you will actually use other weapons, so ya don't have to stick with a lightsaber. You can clear enemies in your path with the force (lightning) and throw enemies of edges using force (grip).  And you can swap between 1st and 3rd person(s) wielding any weapon.Great game for Star Wars fans interested in the Expanded Universe.

												Quite simply the best Star Wars game I have ever played (yes even including Knights of the Old Republic). number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8
												Great game. I replayed it about 6 months ago or so. It's still a lot of fun today. The sense of scale for its time was amazing. Some of the levels are huge and I'll get to this later. The balance of combat, story, and exploration is very much like Jedi Knight 1. Sadly they use in-game models instead of live-action for the cut-scenes. But besides this gripe nearly everything else is a step up. When I say nearly...some of the levels are so large you can get lost. So you end up wandering around until you accidentally stumble upon your next checkpoint kind of thing. Also some of the switches you have to hit...or vents you have to find to crawl through are hidden almost too well. Wouldn't be so bad if these were secrets. But some of these out of the way switches are needed to advance the story. I didn't need any kind of strategy guide (and I'm not some ace gamer) but I do remember a few times I was wandering around only to find what I needed right before calling it quits. Not often. I can remember three spots specifically. Anyhow enemy AI was fair for its time and dated today. STILL....this game is lots of fun. I enjoyed exploring for the most part and looking around. Again the sense of scale in some of the levels were still awesome. And the light sabre battles and force powers were a blast to use in this game. If you like star wars and haven't played this before check it out! The fun factor is still high today. Between JK1, JK2, and Jedi Academy this was my favorite.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												Love this game, have done so since I first set hands on it over 10 years ago. Jedi Knight 2: Jedi Outcast puts you in the head of Kyle Katarn, a Jedi with a conflicted past and uneasy relationship with the force, and takes you through a journey of loss, discovery, gross error and ultimate redemption in the face of a dire threat, marshaled by a Dark Jedi named Dessan, spearheaded by a force of artificially-imbued pseudo-Jedi known as 'Reborn'.The first few levels of the game are a straight forward first-person shooter with puzzle solving elements and some platforming. This is a very well crafted part of the game with strong weapon play (it is respectable that the game developers put the effort into fully fleshing out both portions of the gameplay - both lightsabers and weapons) if slightly outdated AI. The second level in particular - set in a Coruscant-like city of towering blocks and bottomless pits between them named 'Nar Shaddaa' (also seen in TOR, and possibly Bounty Hunter') - features some genuinely devious puzzles and sniper challenges.After these portions of the game, the player takes up the mantel of the Jedi once again - with the assistance of a Mark Hamill-voiced Luke Skywalker - and fights through a number of missions of platforming, puzzle solving, and some exquisitely entertaining lightsaber battles and 'boss' encounters.JKII is a challenging game, long, with well designed levels and graphics that, while ageing, still stand up (and can be modded). Memorable characters, a good story, some twists that are very much in the tradition of the canon and some fantastic cameos by characters from the original Star Wars trilogy all goes together to make this game a must-play.

												10/10 - dgnIf you're keen on immersion in the Star Wars universe, then play this game in first person on Jedi Master difficulty.An underrated amount of quality and care went into this game. - Seriously, I barely know half the lightsaber movements, let alone apply them in a battle.I can keep playing the Single Player campaign once each year, this game is that good. content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												Played through the game for the nth time on hardest difficulty so had to leave a review now. I think this game is a must have for every true Star Wars fan. It's an old game so don't expect beautiful graphics. The story is great. Together with the Star Wars setting and iconic music/effects it gives a great feeling. The lightsabre combat is amazing. It isn't easy though, takes time to master! Even if you think you are a skilled melee fighter by the end of the game, you go online and people will beat you like nothing. Using force powers also really fit into the game, every single force power is useful.What I didn't like the most is the level design. If you play for the first time, you will get stuck everywhere. Sometimes you need to shoot a crate somewhere to blow a hole in the wall or jump on top of a structure which is not self explanaitory. But either you walk around for hours trying to find the way or go online and check a walkthrough (better option).The game forces you to use weapons insead of lightsabre lot of times, because annoying snipers are everywhere. The problem on hardest difficulty is the lack of balance, it surely wasn't tested well. There are some very tough fights, the fight with Lando on Nar Shaddaa, where I was pulling my hair after trying for the hundredth time, while the main fights are quite easy. Beating Tavion wasn't much of a challenge and the final boss is way too easy.All in all a great game with some bad level design, 8/10 would recommend!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 6, 2015
												---------------------------------------------My STAR WARS™ Jedi Knight II - Jedi Outcast™ Review--------------------Oh the nostalgia, I remember in the holidays/weekends, I'd used to get up early in the morning and turn on my Xbox (Original) and put in the disk and wait. I remember killing stormtroopers and getting alot of pleasure out of it. I think I remember putting in a cheat which allowed me to dismember the stormtroopers (which was the best part). -------Story wise----------------Now I haven't played much of the story nor payed alot of attention. When I was a little kid I still didn't care about it. But I can say if you were to read the comic and payed attention it'll be a good story.----------Surroundings----------------Oh this... Now it isn't like the witcher graphics or GTA V but, it's still a good try. From my experience, alot of the levels are just this one big playground to kill stormtroopers or others.Needless to say. The art style is pretty simple. The 'outside world' is all just black and nothing else. Still pretty good.------------Puzzles---------------------------The puzzles are simple but also times can be difficult. I'd find myself going into a walkthrough on just getting to the next bit.---------------Multiplayer-----------------------------Now, I don't remember going into multiplayer alot. But when I did, no-one would be on. It's like a desert out there. Even with bots it still felt pretty lonely. I'd always get my next door friend over but we wouldn't have fun.------------------------------Overall----------------------I do like the story and/or the Level design and stuff. But to be honest. If you haven't played this as a kid  then don't get it. Honestly people just by even without playing as a kid. But this old game is either for Nostalgia or just killing stormtroopers with the dismember cheat. Well, this is my overall review for this game. I'm rating it a Yes for Nostalgia.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												Game is still fun to play after over 10 years. There are some glitches with Multiplayer, such as freezing within 15-20 seconds of a match. I've never had these problems 10 years ago on CD without Steam. I think if you tweak some of the Graphics settings, then most of the glitches go away. For example, don't choose a resolution higher than your screen, turn steam overlay OFF, turn that "EAX" sound option in the game OFF. Single Player is still awesome. Supposedly there is a full HD remake mod coming out someday called "Reborn".Multiplayer is still fun, but hardly anyone plays anymore. I think i've encountered 6-10 real human players so far. Some of these servers trick you by giving unsual names to bots. Trying new skins and mods is still always fun.Other than the lack of players and minor, but fixible glitches, this is still my favourite star wars game of all time.

Posted: November 26, 2013
												Im not sure what to think of this game, when i bought it on release i liked it even if it had some frustrating elements. Such as:* The map designs are awful and you occasionally get stuck wandering about trying to find your way only to realize that you were suppose to go in a direction that doesnt make any sense at all (appearently i wasnt suppose to walk out on the lenghty bridge that looks like its leading on the right direction, instead you have to jump out of a window in a dark corner).* Enemy snipers are ridiculously accurate and fast on the trigger even on normal difficulty.* Scripted ambushes, get used to them.* Hitting enemies with laser pistols and rifles can be a tedious business. Trying to hit constantly strafing foes with laser lights that travel at the speed of small rodents gets old pretty quickly. Instead I just run in a straight line towards them holding down the fire button. Doesnt sound like an intresting gun fight at all now does it.* Grenade throwers, they are everywhere. Strangely enough often in tiny rooms.* Did i hit with my light saber or not? Maybe, who knows. The light saber fights are often just a shiny mess.So there are alot of frustrating issues with the game, but for some reason i keep getting back to it. I turn it off with a sigh but i still start it a few hours again later. So there is obviously some appeal in it, i dont know what it is though =P

Posted: July 4, 2014
												This is such a great game. I remember back when it first came out how amazing it was. It's an FPS where you can also have a lightsaber (it becomes third person for that weapon.) What I remember amazing me when this came out was that the lightsaber actually leaves marks in the wall where you hit it. It was awesome then and is still pretty neat.  I played BioShock: Infinite immediately before Jedi Outcast this time. What struck me was how easy BioShock is compared to this game. In BioShock, all you have to do is push “n” and you see where you have to go. This game hss hardcore puzzle solving with no hints in game. It really is amazing the difference between the games. All in all this is a 10/10 for me. I hope this game is playable on future OS as well. As of now it is very playable on Windows 8, and you can even find a fix online to make the resolution look good on modern screen resolutions. Highly recommended.

Posted: February 10, 2015
												Jedi Outcast is another awesome game.  I play this game yearly with Jedi Academy.  While dated, and not as refined as Jedi Academy as far as light saber combat is involved, it is still a game with an excellent story, good though dated graphics, excellent level design and fun lightsaber combat mechanics.If you can put the graphics asside (which are not THAT bad), you will be enthralwed by a very fun game.  Just a few notes:-SLI usually gives this game some issues, so if you use SLI, turn it off. -There are widescreen profiles online you can use to bump up the resolution somewhat.-The game can be somewhat hard, so save/reload a lot and work your way through that way.  -Missions can sometimes leave you a bit stumped on where to go next, but if you look around, the solutions ARE there, if not, just hit up IGN Jedi Outcast Walkthrough for some solutions.  For example, when trying to escape with Lando, you enter a dark side tunnel and if you forgot about your light amplifaction goggles, you would never know how to get out of that area and advance the mission.  Still, great game.  I wish EA would further the franchise somehow, because these were fantastic.

Posted: December 23, 2012
												Thank Raven for taking this series over, you know, while they were still their own company. Jedi Outcast was an addiction for me for well over a year, with me modding the fudge out of this game and setting up my own epic battles between hundreds of Jedi and Sith every weekend, with hours spent enjoying realistic saber gore. The saber combat was amazing coming off the story-focused prequel, and made the multiplayer an addictive addition (which I totally dominated for months!) to a single-player campaign on the level of the best EU material.While the level design often remains noticeably, remarkably Jedi Knight quality (read: confusing and maze-like), especially early on before you're able to kick total patoot and forget about level confusion.Also, Katarn, Our Hero, has a beard, and he fights a Dramatic Reptile. Game of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed Year.

Posted: February 24, 2016
												This is old-school through and through. In both good and bad.So what's good about it? It does not hold your hand. It does not restrict your actions or freedom. No QTEs of any description. It is bloody hard at places. I cosider myself a very experienced FPS player, and I've beaten this game earlier several times. But jumping into it on third(out of four) difficulty setting resulted in a pretty challenging playthrough, especially before protagonist's rejedification, when you have to rely on conventional weapons.Fighting other jedi is just fantastic, and is still an eye candy after all these years. You can hack them with your lightsaber, use force powers, push them off the ledges, and even cheese them with conventional weapons sometimes, which is not an easy feat to accomplish. Even regular stormtroopers strafe and move around, making them very difficult to hit early on, until you get the hang of it.But all this comes at a price too. Level design is just not very good at times from gameplay perspective. There is quite a bit of platforming, which is exactly as not fun as it sounds. Some environmental puzzles are just too obscure - even having beaten this game earlier I still had to use a walkthrough multiple times. Perhaps I was more patient back in the day... Sometimes you have to do things which are jsut counterintuitive. At one point player has to use force to move a crate to reveal the grate You can use force push and force pull on objects, but this particular crate had to be exactly pulled precisely from the left, it refused to move in any other direction and it made no sense.Also, there is a special place in hell for aimbot rodians with disruptor rifles.Still, this is an enjoyable game to play and replay, but if you are new to hardcore old-scool shooters - tread lightly.P.S. The multiplayer is still alive! I've immediately found several populated servers with <50 ping at 2 A.M.

Posted: November 23, 2016
												I would have to say that this game is the best example of a Star Wars epic. Unlike Knights of the old Republic 1 and 2 that are more like watching several of the movies back to back. This game is like playing through a brand new movie, and a good one at that.Design - 7/10 Yes, the game is old and the cutscenes are hard to look at. The game itself though is quite good looking with very good character models and okay backrounds. Atmosphere is top notch, feeling rich and varied with each location. The one problem with the levels, intresting as they are, is that they can be confusing, and can leave you feeling lost. In my opinion, I've come to like that but when I was younger it was the main reason I had trouble with the game. Gameplay - 9/10 This game makes you feel like a Jedi, in a way no other game has (except the next game Jedi academy, which improves upon it but at the loss of some story). Rewarding you with great power but only after you've earned it, through both great fun and hardship. Using the lightsaber feels fast and fuild, slicing through stromtroppers like butter. Facing other Jedi is a dance of light and sweat, where a single strike can end you. Now when you start you have no lightsaber or force powers and the first few missions can be quite daunting. The gunplay suports these sections, being fast paced and excelent with a wide verity of weapons each having their own uniqueness and usefulness. Sound - 10/10 It's just as it should be with beautiful and entertaining songs taken right from the movies and the striking sounds of blasters going off and lightsabers swinging through the air. It fits perfectly.Overall - 9/10 This is a great game and there needs to be more like it. If they could update this game, better graphics, steam workshop,  and without the problem of running on newer tech, than that would bring new light to this awesome game. (W 8.1 with no problems)

Posted: November 3, 2016
												Background: Don't be turned away by my hours played. I remember spending entire evenings of my childhood playing this on Windows XP. I bought it on Steam because hey, its a classic, oldie with Kyle Katarn (Someone who needs to be on the Silver Screen). Story: The story is great and holds up against the $60 Big Studio and Assorted Indie Games of 2016.  You contend with all the classic enemies like Stormtroopers, AT-ST, Imp Officers, and Bounty Hunters. You even meet Luke Skywalker!Lightsaber Mechanics: A Few levels into the game you go through Jedi Training...Again. Lightsaber Combat has 3 forms. A quick low damage striking form, single hits can still off Stormtroopers. A Medium speed balanced form, and a Heavy hitting Slow form that strangely enough throws off lightsaber wielding opponents. You also pick up your Basic Push, Pull, Jump, Speed Skills. These evolve as the game progresses.All other Combat Mechanics: It becomes your generic shooter with weapons from the Star Wars Universe. Stormtrooper E-11 blaster, Wookie Bowcaster, Thermal Detonators, Trip Mines. It is also challenging and has some puzzles that you have to work your way through.Final Thoughts:  Its a great nostalgic game from years past. I love it because of Star Wars.
