Posted: December 6, 2015
												I won't ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t you guys looking at this game, a lot of people here say it's a good game despite it's age.It is, the lightsaber combat is still un-beaten in my opinion and with the quake engine base you know that you can go crazy bunny hopping and blowing everything in the galaxy just for kicks. A game from time where cover and reload didn't exist.TL;DR :-Game totally worth it if bought on sale, the only reason I think 11.99 is a bit overpriced is because the game is old. If compared to todays (Indie?) game's worth the same price JK II might not come on top. It is fun and a must buy if you like lightsaber and/or wish to play a game with good lightsaber mechanics."Buy the game, worth the bucks if bought in a sale. But don't expect it to be easy, there is a good chance that if you manage not to get killed by blaster rifle yet you'll be ripping your hair off being unable to progress."I'll start with the cons-- The shooting mechanic isn't really optimized, the game was made around the melee lightsaber combat. But on a quake engine. So not only the first two level are a royal pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ You might not feel comfortable blasting away in fear that you won't find more ammo of your favorite gun.- While there is a respectable amount of Force Abilities in game, you'll prefer sticking to one as changing them mid battle doesn't work. Especially late game when you're facing horde's of storm trooper, you'll just use force push and slice them while there still on the ground. Isn't fun but it's way better compared to the next con.- Pathfinding. You're reading that right.Killed every single one of Desann's grunts with wookie blaster shots bouncing off the wall? Well then make sure you have a keen eye, buttons are easy to miss as they blend well with the non interactable environment. It's not like a keen eye wouldn't catch the difference but with the quake engine, I really don't know if it is quake but it quite close. You really don't have the pace, most of the time you're running like your pants would implode if you stopped for too long so it's easy to miss those critical elements, the reason It took me 11.8 hours... yep you guessed it. Running around like a lunatic because I couldn't find that grate on the ceiling.This is the only major flaw, the rest come out pale in front of it.Now the reason you should buy this game, I know I trashed it quite a bit but this is the second time I bought this game. I had gotten the hard copy a decade ago. A decade later- minus a week I bought the game again.If a decade later from today, I lose my steam or for whatever reason I loose this game but I have the opportunity to buy this game again, I would buy it. Obviously not for 20$ or even 11.99$, (bought it cheap on sale), unless the remake the whole game on the latest game engine and tweak some stuff, then price is not a concern.whoops! Well here are the pros- No DLC- No Micro Trasactions- Single Player, multiplayer optional- Decent storyline, kinda like those kebab's you buy off that shady guys stall. You know that it's bad quality and there are better kebab just down the street but you can't be bothered as the kebab in your hand taste just fine, also you aren't dead after eating them.- Light Saber's- You getting your Light Saber back- Mowing down them grunts with Light Saber- Throwing your Light Saber at them grunts- Grunt's with Light Saber- You fighting Grunt's with Light Saber!- Pew Pew Pew!- Aw! Those wall jumps are so sweet!- Mind Control the officer and make him do a dance off with the other officer (Warning, a figment of authors imagination not in game)=======Yeah, I'm gonna take a break now that I've finished the game. In case you do buy the game remember these 2 commandments1. Thou shalt rebind the quick save and quick load key for taking a screenshot with every save is not for the sane.2. Thou shalt quick save whenever there is danger to face, for autosave is a handicap this game laughs at.

Posted: May 2, 2014
												When Lucas Arts was still Lucas Arts they came out with a series of either good or kindof annoying star wars game.  This is inbetween.  Jedi Outcast is one of those games that will rub you wrong for long periods of time, and be very fun for the rest of the time.  First off, I am good at FPS games and this is a half and half on 1st and 3rd person.  As you will be using both guns and your lightsaber.  I played this game the first time on the 2nd difficulty and I found that it was pretty easy to kill enemies with 2-3 hits from the blaster, its a bit annoying that projectiles are slow and you must time it right but you get used to it.  What I cant get used to is the overpowerment of enemies.  There weapons do way to much damage, even utilizing your force powers like speed they still do lots of damage to you and not in the good way.  Also the lightsaber fighting mechanics are not that great.  Kyle acts like the lightsabor is as heavy as a claymore when its supposed to be a very lite weapon, so hes basically swinging it around uncontrollably and slow.  And enemy lightsabors do more damage to you than yours does to them.  Dont try to tell me otherwise I looked in the games files and thats how it actually is.  So I found fighting enemy jedi a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥  However I will say that this game is saved by its lengthy time to finish (19hrs for me on blind run), and the fact that most of your force powers are very good.  Although I dont like how you must use them or else they wont level up, and I know thats how most games work but its not done very well here.  The game also exceeds in being a good fps espiacially for the time.  Your weapons do very good damage most enemies taking only about 4 hits to die.So is it a good fps game?   ♥♥♥♥ NO, its decent but I know it could have been balanced a bit better.  So is it a good Lightsaber game?  ALSO ♥♥♥♥ NO, Im sorry but the fighting mechanics for the lightsaber (only against enemy jedi) was just to challenging.So is it a good star wars game?  Yes it is, its one of the best out there and I recommend any fan to play this game, its well worth a playthrough.  I just wish they did not overpower enemy damage to you.  Dont get me wrong I like it when enemy weapons do a good amount of damage, but this game fails at it.

												Understand one thing before you play this game: the early game sucks.  You don't have your lightsaber, you don't have force powers, and the levels are labyrinthine at times, requiring you to find air ducts and switches in the middle of rooms.  And then you get the lightsaber, and the game throws a thousand snipers at you.  But then...BUT THEN...your force powers get really good.  You start to feel like a truly badass Jedi.  You're hacking your way through hundreds of Stormtroopers, the level designs even out and become slightly more linear (not completely, but enough so you know which way to go), and it just becomes truly fun.  Rough around the edges, but still worth playing today.

												Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast is a prime example of when there were good Star Wars games. It is massively fun to play. The graphics haven't aged particularly well and the level design and gameplay does show its age but that is just part of its charm. I highly recommend it to anyone who loves Star Wars. It is at its best when played with dismemberment turned on. A new entry into the series is just what we need to revitalize Star Wars games. While we wait for just such a title to release enjoy this title from 2002. I love it and you should as well. Because of its age I'll cut it some slack in its short comings. All together you get an awesome story, great acting, fun gameplay, and best of all it feels like you're in the Star Wars universe. I rank this game 9 out of 10.

Posted: May 7, 2014
												This game was really cool. The story was interesting with a lot of familiar faces, which was exciting, the music is typical Star Wars, meaning it's good, and it's just a lot of fun to feel like an empowered bada$$ Jedi Knight. There are a slew of force powers to use on your enemies including the iconic Force Choke (called Force Grip here), Force Jump, Force Push, Force Pull, and even Force Lightning. Yeah. The lightsaber duels are also quite impressive visually, and employ an interesting mechanic that few other games incorporate. Lightsabers do a LOT of damage. A direct hit is a one-hit kill for most enemies. Some of the more powerful ones take a few more hits. That applies to your character too though. One good hit can be the difference between life and death, especially on the harder difficulties, and it gives the lightsaber combat a very frantic feel. The best thing I can really compare it to is Nidhogg, except 3d and you aren't fighting over territory. That being said the lightsaber duels can also drag on for a long period of time, and it's really, in my opinion, as often tedious as it is fun. This franchise started off as a first person shooter, but over time became more and more focused on lightsaber combat and force powers. If you played dark forces or the original Jedi Knight, you may be dissappointed with the direction this game has taken. The lightsaber and force powers have been significantly upgraded from the original Jedi Knight and completely overshadowed the shooting mechanics. The 1st person shooter mechanics are solid, but completely unnecessary. As a matter of fact it's quite likely you'll spend the whole game using your lightsaber after obtaining it and never use a blaster again. You DO have to reach a certain point in the story to unlock your lightsaber and force powers. Overall, I'd highly recommend this game.

Posted: November 19, 2015
												Played this game back in 2003 on Gamecube and loved it. Now I'm playing it with the Steam Controller and it's just as good as I remembered (and the Steam Controller makes it even better!). Posted: November 7, 2015
												This takes everything that was good about the last game and just makes everything even better. The level design is amazing (besides nar shadaa streets - hate that level) and the combination of light saber, force and weapons is handled really well. You very quickly learn that you have the best chance of progressing by using a combination of them all. This always keeps you on your toes!The real highlight of this game though is the lightsaber and the lightsaber battles. It is good fun to use the light saber to cut down the stormtroopers/enemies. But just just wait till you get into 1v1/1v2 jedi fights. At first you'll struggle but keep learning how to fight properly - always make sure to keep moving and the battles will feel amazing. I mean amazing - it really encaptures what a jedi fight would feel like!One key note is the nar shadaa streets level. I found this game really frustrating - you just get a hold of the lightsaber and then you are faced with a level where you can't really use it. Just try persevere through and you'll be rewarded!

Posted: November 27, 2015
												Possibly the best star wars game I've ever played. The lightsaber player is beautiful, better done than any other game in my opinion. It does take some getting used to but once you get in the groove, everythings great.Campaign: 4/5 Lacks a LITTLE bit of depth, but it's a star wars game so you should know most things going in.Multiplayer: 5/5 I can spend countless hours just wittling away at people. Granted mp is kinda dead now, you can find a cult following in a few servers very loyal to the game and the sales should help bring it back a little.Graphics: 3/5 what do you expect it's an older game, may experience some resolution issues. Run in compatibility mode with XP sp3 and run as administrator for the game folder in /steam/steamapps/commonSound: 4/5 Quality is great for what it is. Some of the injury sound files get repetitive. Oh well. For it's time, absolutely amazing.Overall gameplay: 4.8/5 I love this game and would reccomend it to any star wars fan.

Posted: February 29, 2016
												Date: 2/28/16Review Number: 30 Game:Jedi Knight II: Jedi OutcastFrom (Creator Publisher): Raven Software/LucasartsPlayed On: Steambox w/ControllerSteam Price as of Review: $9.99Total Time played: 60 minutesReview:Little bit of disclosure here, the actual game the wheel of morality picked was Dark Forces 2, Jedi Knight, but after spending fifteen minutes getting it to load properly only to find that the game would consistently crash on me on either of my machines, I gave it up as a bad job and moved to the sequel.  and honestly, what a sequel it is, or at least what a sequel I remember it to be, though the actual playtime I had reminded me of exactly how slow the game was to ramp up.  Now, I will say without a doubt that as far as first person shooters go, the Jedi Knight series was, and in a way still is, my favorite FPS series (though that title has been somewhat superseded by the bioshock series in recent years), and for many legitimate reasons outside the whole Star Wars fanboy thing.   The storylines are in depth and give you a characterization that is lost in so many of the other FPS genre, the character models were ahead of their time (that time being very long ago of course, so that doesn't hold quite as much water now) and the game did what I believe was the first well done implementation of third person perspective with a melee weapon that I had seen.  Not to mention all the nice force powers you would get as the game progressed into its later stages.  Though in a way, the end of that statement is one of the game’s flaws; because it's far more story oriented than other FPS games, the actual story itself can lend to slower gameplay, which in the FPS world is something that seems out of place now, even Bioshock was fairly quick to ramp up the special abilities and Plasmids, whereas in the 60 minute playtime I got with this game I wasn't even close to getting my lightsaber.All that being said of course, this is no reason to dislike the game, it has just become one of those games that you want to take more time with, as opposed to the quick and dirty games that I've been reviewing lately.  This is a good thing, really, but it just means that I can’t really review this one as thoroughly as I can many other games.  But still, on the potential that one hour of playtime has on it's own, this game can certainly stand a cut above most of the other FPS games of it's time, and is a definite buy from me.Game’s Fate: Uninstalled, but not for the merits of the game itself, just more that I know that Jedi Academy is better, so Ill wait for that to keepBuy/No Buy: If you haven’t played it, you definitely should.  Even if Kyle is no longer canon, It's still a interesting story, and worth the playtime.  Buy

Posted: January 11, 2016
												Jedi Outcast is in my opinion the best Star Wars game ever made, and one of my personal favourite games. Outcast, and its sequel Jedi Academy, have undoubtedly the best lightsaber combat of any Star Wars game. You have fantastic control over the lightsaber, and combined with the excellent selection of force powers and fantastic gun-play, the combat as a whole is extremely satisfying. The story is adequate at best, and the platforming can be a little tricky, but these are the only negatives I can see. The level design is very good too, as it is with the rest of the Dark Forces/Jedi Knight series.9/10 If you are a Star Wars fan you really should already have this game.

Posted: January 15, 2014
												I first played this on on my PC.  It was the demo version from the E3 show this was revealed at.  I enjoyed everything about the lightsaber powers, the shooting, the music, everything about this game is Star Wars.  It takes more from the prequel trilogy in terms of its lightsaber combat with Kyle doing flips, and the action being much faster.  Thats not a bad thing at all. I bought the Gamecube version which was terrible and blurry and my biggest regret but the problem was my PC was a family PC and there was not enough HD space left for the game.  About a   year ago, I found out this game and the previous Dark Forces games were on steam as a bundle and it was an instant buy for me.  The story takes place after RotJ where Kyle must learn to become a Jedi Knight again after his partner Jane was "killed" by a dark Jedi namned Kasan.   So many different worlds to explore like Nar Shadda, Bespin, the valley of the jedi, a massive star destroyer.  It all feels like a Star Wars game set in the Star Wars universe.  I never played the multiplayer of the game since at the time it was the gamecube version and by the time i bought this for pc it was way past its prime.  A must buy for any Star Wars fan!!!

Posted: May 5, 2015
												When I was younger I didn't have much patience with this game because I didn't really enjoyed killing enemies with blasters (I already had my share of it by playing "Dark Forces" before). Besides that detail, the maps and some of the puzzles can be quite confusing and that is a very effective way to screw up with someone's patience (at least that's what I think). Either way, the more that you advance in the game, the better it gets. Even though I still think that Jedi Academy is a much better option while compared to this one, it surely deserves a share of attention. That's because besides the campaign, the multiplayer mode is quite awesome, I've spent a whole lot of time on it, even fighting against bots. By the way, that's the sort of game that can get extremely funny if you happen to turn on the cheats in certain places (especially to put you inside of places that you're never supposed to reach). Have fun!

Posted: January 2, 2011
												The first part of this game is somewhat disappointing at first, because you start with no light sabre or force powers, but if you can get past that, it's actually a lot of fun. The storm troopers are actually really fun enemies to fight, because they use their environment and superior numbers in quite clever ways, ducking into doorways or behind crates and firing on you from cover, using both fire modes of their weapons when appropriate, and attempting to surround you or attack from multiple directions.And then after a few levels you get your light sabre and force powers and an already fun game just takes a huge step up. There's nothing like grabbing a storm trooper with your mind and throwing him off a bridge, or dueling with light sabres and force powers. That♥♥♥♥♥♥just never gets old.

Posted: March 11, 2015
												After playing through Dark Forces 1 and 2 im finally back to the game in the series that started it for me, Jedi Knight 2. Stepping back into Katarns shoes was a trip down memory lane. I still got stuck at the same frustating bits of level design as I did back in 2002, but having said that this was probably the best game in the series. The 3D graphics had hit a level where round things were starting to look like round things, and the lightsaber/force power combat had been improved. 												Easily the best game in the Jedi Knight series!It continues the story from Jedi Knight: Dark Forces II and gives a very plausible back story of why Kyle Katarn no longer has any force powers to begin with. This make sense since he became a Jedi because he had to, not because he wanted to.The game focuses a lot on action and follows a very well made story line. Force Powers and Lightsabers are now mandatory features and both are executed very well. Lazer blasters work much better, sound effects are great and the variation in level design is just awesome.The Jedi Knight series is not the best game series in the whole world, and the bad guy "Desann" is really, really forgettable. It is however a very good action shooter and you do feel like a jedi. Posted: January 31, 2015
												What is it about Jedi Outcast that makes it worth revisiting 13 years on (and counting)?  Its predecessor, Dark Forces II, was the last great Star Wars title to be developed in house by LucasArts, at a time when the studio was just at the peak of its creative powers and not yet in decline.  We might even remember DFII as the best shooter of the 1990s, were it not for a little game by Valve that came out just over a year later in 1998.Of course, 4.5 years is an eternity in gaming.  By the time Jedi Outcast hit market in 2002, LucasArts' catchet had taken some major hits, thanks to post-Episode I Star Wars titles that were lazy cash grabs at worst (Jedi Power Battles) or disappointing failures at best (*cough*Force Commander*cough*).  Jedi Outcast was developed by a third party, Raven Software, using the Quake III engine; gone are the quirks and charms of the proprietary engines that powered the earlier games in the Dark Forces series.  Moreover, there's a definite emphasis on straight-up action, rather than the vertiginous, puzzle-filled vibe of the first two titles.So why is this game so much damn fun?Although JO takes a while to hit the ground running with its blaster-only prologue missions, there's an immensely satisfying payoff once the player begins Jedi training.  If wielding the lightsaber for the first time in JK:DFII was a cool feeling, then in JO it was absolutely mind blowing: there is a level of fluidity, control, and power that is unique to Raven's treatment of the lightsaber here, and it's apparent from the moment you first use it.  One can honestly say, even after all these years, that there has never been an objectively better representation of lightsaber combat in a Star Wars game,  And the Force powers?  While some players will miss JK:DFII's RPG-lite system, which allowed one to invest in some powers instead of others, it has to be said that Raven took an interesting approach here: not only are most of the iconic powers retained (push, pull, jump, speed, choke, lightning, etc.), but the leveling is handled so discreetly that it's hard not to be impressed by how POWERFUL you really are late in the game -- and, wow, is it a treat to take down entire rooms of enemies with nothing but your saber, the Force, and the extremely tight controls you'd expect of a Quake III-powered game.The story is hardly award winning stuff, but it's conveyed effectively within the gameplay itself.  As a result, JO has a solid momentum that builds in intensity as the game progresses, until the player is continuing on just to see what crazy cool thing they'll get to do next.  (DO, not WATCH; take note, present-day devs.)Throw in a multiplayer mode that's just about everything you'd want a sabers-and-Force-powers multiplayer experience to be, and there's not much else to say about this game.  Raven might not have made a 1:1 follow-up to the Dark Forces games -- how could they? -- but they more than made up for it by delivering the most exciting Jedi action yet seen in the series, or really any Star Wars title.  I still fire this game up once every several years just to see how it's aged, and each time I'm impressed by how much of a blast it still is.  It's not mere nostalgia at work; it's quality design and honest fun delivered by a talented group of people who set out to capture a very specific kind of action-gaming experience, all while remaining true to the spirit of a classic game series.  If you're a Star Wars fan, or even just a shooter fan looking for something slightly different, this is really one of the most entertaining titles out there.  This game lives up to its pedigree in a big way.

Posted: December 16, 2014
												Hands down the best Star Wars FPS/Action game I have ever played. (Admittedly I never played the prequels)You play as Kyle Katarn, a Mercenary that works for the New Republic. You start the game by infiltrating a remnant imperial forces base armed with a basic blaster pistol, and as the game progresses you will get your hands on more weapons (like the iconic E11 Rifle, and a variety of other weapons). You and your wife (Jan Ors) are the only two people in the galaxy who know where a certain "Valley of the Jedi" is located, it contains a Force Nexus so powerful, that anyone who enters it will have their force sensitivity massively boosted. (In other words it can artificially create Jedi, or make Jedi who enter it much stronger) and this has been the focal point of the series up till this entry.The difficulty curve for the first couple of missions isn't exactly forgiving, but after a certain point you start using force powers and a lightsaber which would make everything significantly easier... If you wouldn't have to be facing grenadiers and snipers (which the lightsaber can't block) as soon as you get your hands on the saber. I'd say the real relaxing fun of making minced meat out of stormtroopers doesn't start until after the point where you first start fighting other Jedi in the game, which is about a quarter into the game.But the difficulty of the game is really just what you select when you start it. Hard is hard, medium is medium and easy is easy.Sadly, the game's age does show on modern high resolution displays, it was made for the era of 1024x768. You will see some artifacts (like green tinted shadows) and some heavily upscaled textures. But it's still worth it. It's also worth noting that the multiplayer gameplay in these games is quite fun. How many games allow you to switch between third person lightsaber and first person shooting on the fly when you're fighting other players? Not many.

There's nothing like grabbing a storm trooper with your mind and throwing him off a bridge, or dueling with light sabres and force powers. That♥♥♥♥♥♥just never gets old.

Posted: November 30, 2013
												If you like lightsaber fighting, then JKII Outcast is a solid choice.  It's single player campaign has a respectable ammount of play hours and some replay value but the multiplayer is where it's at.  You can host your own games with full bot support, or join others on dedicated and non-dedicated servers.  There is still a decent player base online regularly and some very good servers are up and running strong.  This game was built on the QIII engine so it runs pretty smooth for most and if there are particular OS, driver or hardware issues, the QIII engine is tried and true so there are solutions to be found.May the force be with you.

Posted: January 21, 2015
												I haven't played Jedi Academy yet, but I can safely say that Jedi Outcast is superior to Dark Forces and Jedi Knight (and far, far superior to Mysteries of the Sith). It has the same fun combat (with a lightsaber, many other Star Wars weapons, and Force powers) that made Jedi Knight such a good game, and it this time it has 21st century graphics, legitimately good voice acting, and a stronger story. It's in the period when Luke's Jedi were headquartered on Yavin 4, and it pits Kyle Katarn against a really great set of new villains while sending him to a lot of iconic Star Wars locations. Unfortunately, the platforming which has been my bane throughout the series is still here. If you love platforming, that will be a plus, but for me, it's the one thing I don't like about this game. (Of course, you can save at any time, so at least it's manageable).I'd say this is the third-best Star Wars shooter ever made (right after Battlefront II and Republic Commando). If you are a Star Wars fan (especially an Expanded Universe lover like me), and/or enjoyed previous games in the Dark Forces/ Jedi Knight series, I recommend this game. If you're interested in the Jedi Knight games but don't want to play something with extremely dated graphics, then this is my recommended jumping-in point.

Posted: January 31, 2015
												What is it about Jedi Outcast that makes it worth revisiting 13 years on (and counting)?  Its predecessor, Dark Forces II, was the last great Star Wars title to be developed in house by LucasArts, at a time when the studio was just at the peak of its creative powers and not yet in decline.  We might even remember DFII as the best shooter of the 1990s, were it not for a little game by Valve that came out just over a year later in 1998.Of course, 4.5 years is an eternity in gaming.  By the time Jedi Outcast hit market in 2002, LucasArts' catchet had taken some major hits, thanks to post-Episode I Star Wars titles that were lazy cash grabs at worst (Jedi Power Battles) or disappointing failures at best (*cough*Force Commander*cough*).  Jedi Outcast was developed by a third party, Raven Software, using the Quake III engine; gone are the quirks and charms of the proprietary engines that powered the earlier games in the Dark Forces series.  Moreover, there's a definite emphasis on straight-up action, rather than the vertiginous, puzzle-filled vibe of the first two titles.So why is this game so much damn fun?Although JO takes a while to hit the ground running with its blaster-only prologue missions, there's an immensely satisfying payoff once the player begins Jedi training.  If wielding the lightsaber for the first time in JK:DFII was a cool feeling, then in JO it was absolutely mind blowing: there is a level of fluidity, control, and power that is unique to Raven's treatment of the lightsaber here, and it's apparent from the moment you first use it.  One can honestly say, even after all these years, that there has never been an objectively better representation of lightsaber combat in a Star Wars game,  And the Force powers?  While some players will miss JK:DFII's RPG-lite system, which allowed one to invest in some powers instead of others, it has to be said that Raven took an interesting approach here: not only are most of the iconic powers retained (push, pull, jump, speed, choke, lightning, etc.), but the leveling is handled so discreetly that it's hard not to be impressed by how POWERFUL you really are late in the game -- and, wow, is it a treat to take down entire rooms of enemies with nothing but your saber, the Force, and the extremely tight controls you'd expect of a Quake III-powered game.The story is hardly award winning stuff, but it's conveyed effectively within the gameplay itself.  As a result, JO has a solid momentum that builds in intensity as the game progresses, until the player is continuing on just to see what crazy cool thing they'll get to do next.  (DO, not WATCH; take note, present-day devs.)Throw in a multiplayer mode that's just about everything you'd want a sabers-and-Force-powers multiplayer experience to be, and there's not much else to say about this game.  Raven might not have made a 1:1 follow-up to the Dark Forces games -- how could they? -- but they more than made up for it by delivering the most exciting Jedi action yet seen in the series, or really any Star Wars title.  I still fire this game up once every several years just to see how it's aged, and each time I'm impressed by how much of a blast it still is.  It's not mere nostalgia at work; it's quality design and honest fun delivered by a talented group of people who set out to capture a very specific kind of action-gaming experience, all while remaining true to the spirit of a classic game series.  If you're a Star Wars fan, or even just a shooter fan looking for something slightly different, this is really one of the most entertaining titles out there.  This game lives up to its pedigree in a big way.

Posted: May 16, 2013
												The adventures of everyone’s favorite Kyle Katarn continue in another thrilling Jedi Knight game.  And who doesn’t love Kyle anyways?  He’s often been referred to as the Chuck Norris of Star Wars.  And to people that care about Chuck Norris that probably means something.  For me personally, Kyle as seen in these games is more annoying that the Kyle you read about in many of the books.But I’m not reviewing the latest Fate of the Jedi book, is that series still popular?  I’m way behind on my Star Wars novels unfortunately.  We’re here to talk about the next in the Jedi Knight series, Star Wars Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast.  This time Kyle is back, and what starts with a blue milk run quickly becomes a quest fueled by anger and revenge.As the Wikipedia blurb said, assuming anybody actually reads those, Jedi Outcast uses the Quake III: Team Area engine.  This means we are guaranteed to have a pretty good looking game, ID Tech III was first seen in Quake III Arena back in 1999.  It was a beautiful game then, and personally is still a beautiful game.  While there will always be things that could be picked at about the engine, and all the games that run on it, it will remain in my book as one of the best looking engines out there.Jedi Outcast starts off kinda slow, but does pick up its pace once you get your hands on your lightsaber.  Which for me took about 4 hours.  I’m not going to lie, I had a really tough time with this game for some reason.  I’ve played it through in the past, but long enough ago that everything was still new to me.  In fact it wasn’t until I got the lightsaber that I realized that I had in fact play Jedi Outcast.Something about the combat mechanics didn’t agree with me, and while there were some valid complaints.  Things like the Imperial Officers take more damage than the Stormtroopers.  Stormtroopers that are wearing armor while the Officers simply have their dress uniforms.  It would appear that a cotton polyester blend can withstand blaster fire better than the standard issue plastoid armor.  Someone should tell Requisitions about this, could save the Empire billions of credits.You know that line from A New Hope?  Where Ben Kenobi says that a lightsaber isn’t as clumsy or random as a blaster.  Thereby implying that blasters are both clumsy and random.  Well it seems like the developers took that line from the movie and placed it at the core of their combat mechanics.  You could fire a blaster six times without moving the mouse and you’ll hit at six different locations.  The blasters have a fan effect, one that is made worse if you use the rapid-fire.While the previous games had a similar fanning of the blaster bolts, they also had an auto-aim that counter balanced it.  You didn’t have to be a perfect shot, the blaster would make up for what you lacked in skill.  Here they’ve done away with the auto-aim, but left the fanning.  Personally, I don’t think Ben was being very literal when he made that statement.  Not to the extent that this game makes it seem.The story I’d call above average, but still falls to some standard video game issues.  As with many games there are aspects or parts of the story that feel like they are only there for something to do.  Otherwise, were it simply a written story, the segment would have been left out.  But I’d can’t blame a game for these moments, as all games tend to have them.  The developers want to keep the action up, or to showcase a specific feature or ability in the game, and write a level into the story just for that purpose.  Its a common trait, and one that we games have gotten used to.  And the better writers and developers can do this, and blend it into the story so well that we tend to not even notice it on the first pass.Jedi Outcast has the expected character cameos of Luke Skywalker, Mon Mothma, Jan Ors, and Lando Calrissian.  And best of all is that Billy Dee Williams actually voiced Lando, giving the character a little more love than the others.  Although it was a pretty big coincidence that Kyle should happen to be stranded in the same place where Lando is locked up.But convenient coincidences aside, the story holds it own with the average of today.  As well as the bulk of the gameplay, controls, and puzzles have all aged well.  The blasters could use a little work, and perhaps a texture update and you have something that beats a lot of today’s releases.  In fact this would be a great game to get a HD remake.  And there are probably a couple of other things that I just can’t think of right now, but I guess they’re not that important.

Posted: January 21, 2015
												I haven't played Jedi Academy yet, but I can safely say that Jedi Outcast is superior to Dark Forces and Jedi Knight (and far, far superior to Mysteries of the Sith). It has the same fun combat (with a lightsaber, many other Star Wars weapons, and Force powers) that made Jedi Knight such a good game, and it this time it has 21st century graphics, legitimately good voice acting, and a stronger story. It's in the period when Luke's Jedi were headquartered on Yavin 4, and it pits Kyle Katarn against a really great set of new villains while sending him to a lot of iconic Star Wars locations. Unfortunately, the platforming which has been my bane throughout the series is still here. If you love platforming, that will be a plus, but for me, it's the one thing I don't like about this game. (Of course, you can save at any time, so at least it's manageable).I'd say this is the third-best Star Wars shooter ever made (right after Battlefront II and Republic Commando). If you are a Star Wars fan (especially an Expanded Universe lover like me), and/or enjoyed previous games in the Dark Forces/ Jedi Knight series, I recommend this game. Posted: January 21, 2015
												I haven't played Jedi Academy yet, but I can safely say that Jedi Outcast is superior to Dark Forces and Jedi Knight (and far, far superior to Mysteries of the Sith). It has the same fun combat (with a lightsaber, many other Star Wars weapons, and Force powers) that made Jedi Knight such a good game, and it this time it has 21st century graphics, legitimately good voice acting, and a stronger story. It's in the period when Luke's Jedi were headquartered on Yavin 4, and it pits Kyle Katarn against a really great set of new villains while sending him to a lot of iconic Star Wars locations. Unfortunately, the platforming which has been my bane throughout the series is still here. If you love platforming, that will be a plus, but for me, it's the one thing I don't like about this game. (Of course, you can save at any time, so at least it's manageable).I'd say this is the third-best Star Wars shooter ever made (right after Battlefront II and Republic Commando). If you are a Star Wars fan (especially an Expanded Universe lover like me), and/or enjoyed previous games in the Dark Forces/ Jedi Knight series, I recommend this game. If you're interested in the Jedi Knight games but don't want to play something with extremely dated graphics, then this is my recommended jumping-in point.

Posted: January 31, 2015
												What is it about Jedi Outcast that makes it worth revisiting 13 years on (and counting)?  Its predecessor, Dark Forces II, was the last great Star Wars title to be developed in house by LucasArts, at a time when the studio was just at the peak of its creative powers and not yet in decline.  We might even remember DFII as the best shooter of the 1990s, were it not for a little game by Valve that came out just over a year later in 1998.Of course, 4.5 years is an eternity in gaming.  By the time Jedi Outcast hit market in 2002, LucasArts' catchet had taken some major hits, thanks to post-Episode I Star Wars titles that were lazy cash grabs at worst (Jedi Power Battles) or disappointing failures at best (*cough*Force Commander*cough*).  Jedi Outcast was developed by a third party, Raven Software, using the Quake III engine; gone are the quirks and charms of the proprietary engines that powered the earlier games in the Dark Forces series.  Moreover, there's a definite emphasis on straight-up action, rather than the vertiginous, puzzle-filled vibe of the first two titles.So why is this game so much damn fun?Although JO takes a while to hit the ground running with its blaster-only prologue missions, there's an immensely satisfying payoff once the player begins Jedi training.  If wielding the lightsaber for the first time in JK:DFII was a cool feeling, then in JO it was absolutely mind blowing: there is a level of fluidity, control, and power that is unique to Raven's treatment of the lightsaber here, and it's apparent from the moment you first use it.  One can honestly say, even after all these years, that there has never been an objectively better representation of lightsaber combat in a Star Wars game,  And the Force powers?  While some players will miss JK:DFII's RPG-lite system, which allowed one to invest in some powers instead of others, it has to be said that Raven took an interesting approach here: not only are most of the iconic powers retained (push, pull, jump, speed, choke, lightning, etc.), but the leveling is handled so discreetly that it's hard not to be impressed by how POWERFUL you really are late in the game -- and, wow, is it a treat to take down entire rooms of enemies with nothing but your saber, the Force, and the extremely tight controls you'd expect of a Quake III-powered game.The story is hardly award winning stuff, but it's conveyed effectively within the gameplay itself.  As a result, JO has a solid momentum that builds in intensity as the game progresses, until the player is continuing on just to see what crazy cool thing they'll get to do next.  (DO, not WATCH; take note, present-day devs.)Throw in a multiplayer mode that's just about everything you'd want a sabers-and-Force-powers multiplayer experience to be, and there's not much else to say about this game.  Raven might not have made a 1:1 follow-up to the Dark Forces games -- how could they? -- but they more than made up for it by delivering the most exciting Jedi action yet seen in the series, or really any Star Wars title.  I still fire this game up once every several years just to see how it's aged, and each time I'm impressed by how much of a blast it still is.  It's not mere nostalgia at work; it's quality design and honest fun delivered by a talented group of people who set out to capture a very specific kind of action-gaming experience, all while remaining true to the spirit of a classic game series.  If you're a Star Wars fan, or even just a shooter fan looking for something slightly different, this is really one of the most entertaining titles out there.  This game lives up to its pedigree in a big way.

Posted: July 7, 2016
												Star Wars Jedi Knight II - Jedi Outcast was a classic Star Wars game even when came out back in 2002. It is the fourth entry in the Jedi Knight series, and keeps the same great combat and feel of the older games, while still managing to keep things fresh. I play the game on the hardest difficulty, and while it might seem gruelingly hard, the experience is more rewarding than many of the games that have come out in the 14 years since it's release. The gameplay is well polished and most importantly, fun, as it keeps you wanting to go back to it time and time again. The story is also good, pulling upon and expanding the already deep lore of the Star Wars Expanded Universe that takes place after Return of the Jedi. It also features the best lightsaber combat in any Star Wars Game. Ever. All of that combines to create a timeless classic that'll have fans coming back for years to come. I give Star Wars Jedi Knight II - Jedi Outcast, an 8.75/10

Posted: July 21, 2016

Posted: July 19, 2016
												There are a couple reasons why I recommend this game;It's smart- what I mean by that is the game doesn't baby you or hold your hand. You're dropped into the action from the start and left to figure out where to go and what to do on your own in relatively large, somewhat non-linear levels. I could almost compare it in that respect to a game like Half-Life.It holds up well- This game is 13 years old, and while it shows through in some places, like widesreen resolutions not being supported in the options menu (although this is easily fixed by tweaking a config file), the visuals and physics are still solid at worst (generally they're fantastic), and the sound quality is absolutely amazing, unlike a lot of other older games which I find the sound quality is really scratchy a lot of the time. It feels like a game that came out maybe in the early 2010s, and not '03.Low price- while $11 may be a slight stretch, the price often drops to less than $2 during sales, so you'll be getting a lot of bang for your buck.Fun as hell- a game could have the best graphics, biggest maps, most sophisticated ai, etc etc, but if it isn't fun I see no point in playing it. I bought this game dirt cheap cause I love Star Wars and have heard nothing but good things about this series, and while it isn't a game that I'll play for large amounts of time consistently like an online fps, every time I'm bored and not really sure what to play, I always find myself booting this game up and having an absolute blast for an hour or two at a time.The only con I have is that when I started this game up a few days ago my previous saves were gone, but I wasnt that far in anyway so It wasn't a problem, but I definitely wouldn't have been happy if I'd made significant progress. Ohter than that, if youve got a bit of extra cash and you're into Star Wars, I'd definitely say you should get this game.

												Pros:Lightsaber duels are awesomeThe sounds in this game are incredible. The soundtrack for this game includes all of the familiar Star Wars themes. The sounds of the blasters and lightsabers are true to the movies. The story is solid. Guest appearances from some of my favorite Star Wars characters. The graphics are good for a game that came out more than a decade ago. Cons:The level design. Some of the levels are downright annoying and tedious. On several occassion I couldn't figure out where I had to go next. The time it took me to figure out where to go really disrupted the flow of the game. No instructions on how to properly wield the lightsaber. The battles with the Dark Jedi can get tought simply because there is no tutorial on how to effectively use the lightsaber. In order to get the game to run on my computer I had to download a dll file. If not, the game would crash on startup.

												STAR WARS Jedi Knight II - Jedi Outcast is a sequel of a sequel, branching out from the Dark Forces games still staring the protagonist Kyle Katarn who at this point in the series has given up his Jedi powers and has taken up the job of mercenary work, only to be forced to become a Jedi again after losing someone dear to him. I would recommend this game if you like a challenge.

Posted: November 2, 2016
Product received for free
Disclaimer : I got this game for almost nothing in some Star Wars Humble Bundle that i bought for other games a few year back, that's why i'm considering i got the game for free (probably for less than 0.25€)I hadn't played this game for more than 10 years... A friend lent me the game back then, but i never finished it. When i noticed it in my Steam library this week-end so i decided to give it another try. The game is a blend of FPS and third person lightsaber combat. Weapons feel responsive, sound great, and carry the nostalgia of these early-2000s Star Wars games. The graphics are not bad, they aged well in my opinion and i'm genuinely still amazed by the marks left by lightsabers on walls.Now for the cons :* First it's clearly not worth 10€ in 2016.* Some game mechanics are NOT introduced, i discovered that i could use objects, after being stuck for half an hour in the only part of the game that really require using them (The nightvision goggles in the hangar level). Moreover, i only discovered during the final level that i could heal myself using a force power. (Explaining why the last levels were so hard, since medipacs were not provided anymore as i was supposed to use the force...) * Talking about levels, they seem well designed at first glance, but they are a labyrinthic mess. Prepare to run around levels you just cleared for hours before finding out an utterly hidden ventilation grid on the ceiling of a random room that will lead to the next part of it. This happens in every level and i wasn't prepared for that. I still can't believe some levels of this game made it through QA and play-testing, as half of them require you to perform jumps that would have been considered as glitch/skips in any decently-designed game.TL;DR : This is overall a good experience, but kinda frustrating if you are used to modern games that have corrected the youthful errors of this one over a decade. 6.5/10

The gameplay is very fun as well. While it does take a good two to three hours before you obtain your lightsaber, the first four levels that are strictly a FPS affair are very fun and challenging, and when you do get your hands on the lightsaber, the game becomes even more fun and intense! The story is also very well done picking up a year or so after Jedi Knight: Dark Forces II. You'll meet several characters from the films including Luke and Lando (voiced by the always amazing Billy Dee Willams). Overall this game is near perfection and I highly recommend that anyone, wheather a fan of Star Wars, FPS', or both should definitely pick up.

Posted: May 14, 2016
												Overall Jedi Outcast holds up rather well.  It does show its age with a few things, level design is a bit patchy and frustrating, getting hit with snipers that are impossible to see until they shoot you (one hit death depending on how much shields you have/difficulty level) and there can be 3 snipers lined up to take you out in one spot, so killing one only is pointless.  That's just one example, but generally it's ok.The lightsaber mechanics are a bit sloppy which I never noticed way back when, but after playing Jedi Academy, which has a weaker story, but it's combat is slightly improved and flows much better than Outcast.  If you combined the often fun Level design and lightsaber mechanics of acadamy into Jedi Outcast, I think you'd have an almost flawless game.  As it is, it's a classic with a few cracks showing.As a FPS it's good, but not great, hit recognition is VERY random at times.As a jedi... lightsaber.. thing.. it's good but not great, for reasons just mentioned.But the story and of course Star wars univers, music etc, are all used very well and lift it up a notch.  Great to see a reasonable 'conclusion' to the story of the character, having followed him since his old days of Dark Forces.

Posted: May 13, 2015
												(CONTAINS ONE SPOILER) Is a great game till now and was even better when it came out. So what makes it great? Thats kinda simple:+Star Wars-like, convincing dialouges which are quite hilarious sometimes+Balanced Force Powers make you feel like a real Jedi, not like an overpowered demigod (i.e Force Unleashed). The Force is strong in this one though.+Interesting, though not very logical level design in terms of realism at least+Its not just a shooter but also includes some riddles/puzzles (if thats not your thing, check the net for solutions)+Funny, sometimes a bit ridicoulous ragdolls which may cheer you up immensely+Steer an ATST (ok, its just a short level, but hey, reduce difficulty to zero for one level relaxes the game nicely)+9/10 People who have given this game a bad review are not blaming the gameplay, but the compatibility issues with win7/mac (I had none so far with win7 and perhaps one should not buy a mac and then complain that games are incompatible)+Still a better love story than Twilight+Features mods and some nice MP-modes (like Jedi Master, Holocron, etc)WARNING: This game may be inconvenient for you if you are unaccustomed to what I call the "old-school"-Shooters, that said you have no regenerating health or objective markers that take you by the hand.Whats bad about it:Hm, well I guess lightsaber duels are not as good as they could be since its mostly fumbling around waiting for you or the enemy to die. But against enemies without lightsabers it works pretty well.Some people complain about the fact that the crosshair wavers under certain circumstances like running up to a wall. In my personal opinion that is confusing but has a good reason: Since you are shooting "from the hip", holding your gun in the right hand, so the Projectile travels from slightly right of you towards your target. When you move towards a close Enemy/Wall your crosshair deviates towards the hand holding the weapon which may be unnerving but also making the game more realistic (since you dont hold the gun centered in front of you like in Doom.

Posted: February 24, 2016
												A surprisingly good game! I, myself, am a huge Star Wars fan and this is legitimately a very good expanded universe game with a lot of good references to the original trilogy, a good story, good characters and also very enjoyable, challenging puzzles that make the game more fun. The only thing I would say would be that the combat isn't that great, and sometimes enemies don't respond well to the hits they take. Also I would say the inventory is too hard to use, and medpacks don't appear frequently enough as you lose health at a very fast rate. All that aside, though, it's a good game and I would recommend it.

Posted: January 11, 2016
												Jedi Outcast is in my opinion the best Star Wars game ever made, and one of my personal favourite games. Outcast, and its sequel Jedi Academy, have undoubtedly the best lightsaber combat of any Star Wars game. You have fantastic control over the lightsaber, and combined with the excellent selection of force powers and fantastic gun-play, the combat as a whole is extremely satisfying. The story is adequate at best, and the platforming can be a little tricky, but these are the only negatives I can see. The level design is very good too, as it is with the rest of the Dark Forces/Jedi Knight series.9/10 If you are a Star Wars fan you really should already have this game.

												My first experience into this game was many many years ago when I was a youngster..Returning to it recently made me rethink my childhood nostalgia to the result of it being a far better game than I remembered.. and that I was a fool on some of the puzzle sections!An enjoyable experience that shows the force in full power before the force unleashed stole that title, yet the writing is a hell of alot stronger than most star wars games after this title.If you're a fan of the series, especially of the expanded universe get this game!and have a look at the others in this series of games even if they don't look graphically amazing the story is great for a game of old!

Posted: January 4, 2016
												Pros:Lightsaber duels are awesomeThe sounds in this game are incredible. The soundtrack for this game includes all of the familiar Star Wars themes. The sounds of the blasters and lightsabers are true to the movies. The story is solid. Guest appearances from some of my favorite Star Wars characters. The graphics are good for a game that came out more than a decade ago. Cons:The level design. Some of the levels are downright annoying and tedious. On several occassion I couldn't figure out where I had to go next. The time it took me to figure out where to go really disrupted the flow of the game. No instructions on how to properly wield the lightsaber. The battles with the Dark Jedi can get tought simply because there is no tutorial on how to effectively use the lightsaber. In order to get the game to run on my computer I had to download a dll file. If not, the game would crash on startup.

												If you are trying to decide to get either jedi outcast or jedi academy then let me tell you; If you are looking for a good singleplayer experience with a amazing campaign then get outcast. If your looking to play multiplayer than get academy, there are still servers up with people playing in jedi academy you just have to download a mod to play multiplayer thats all. Posted: July 19, 2016
												There are a couple reasons why I recommend this game;It's smart- what I mean by that is the game doesn't baby you or hold your hand. You're dropped into the action from the start and left to figure out where to go and what to do on your own in relatively large, somewhat non-linear levels. I could almost compare it in that respect to a game like Half-Life.It holds up well- This game is 13 years old, and while it shows through in some places, like widesreen resolutions not being supported in the options menu (although this is easily fixed by tweaking a config file), the visuals and physics are still solid at worst (generally they're fantastic), and the sound quality is absolutely amazing, unlike a lot of other older games which I find the sound quality is really scratchy a lot of the time. It feels like a game that came out maybe in the early 2010s, and not '03.Low price- while $11 may be a slight stretch, the price often drops to less than $2 during sales, so you'll be getting a lot of bang for your buck.Fun as hell- a game could have the best graphics, biggest maps, most sophisticated ai, etc etc, but if it isn't fun I see no point in playing it. I bought this game dirt cheap cause I love Star Wars and have heard nothing but good things about this series, and while it isn't a game that I'll play for large amounts of time consistently like an online fps, every time I'm bored and not really sure what to play, I always find myself booting this game up and having an absolute blast for an hour or two at a time.The only con I have is that when I started this game up a few days ago my previous saves were gone, but I wasnt that far in anyway so It wasn't a problem, but I definitely wouldn't have been happy if I'd made significant progress. Ohter than that, if youve got a bit of extra cash and you're into Star Wars, I'd definitely say you should get this game.

Posted: May 10, 2015
												Even after 12 years this game still holds up. I have never played this game before I bought it on Steam last week (May the 4th sales FTW!) and I can honestly say that even without nostalgia glasses this game is pretty great.If you're looking for a Star Wars game that lets you experience the power of a Jedi, and KotoR's turn based gameplay while good, didn't give you the experience you were after - look no further. Both Jedi Outcast and Jedi Academy are some of the best Jedi games I've ever played.Also, did I mention there was dismemberment? Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥there is. You can chop off hands, arms, heads, legs and bisect them horizontally at the waist, all at once! Killing stormtroopers and sith has never been so fun!I wrote instructions on how to enable full dismemberment here: http://pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Star_Wars:_Jedi_Knight_II_%E2%80%93_Jedi_Outcast#Enabling_full_dismemberment I highly recommend this game to any Star Wars fan looking for a compelling shooter or jedi action experience.

Posted: July 27, 2014
												Best Star wars game in existence.Been playing for at least 11 years and I still love it.(Don't mind the hours through Steam, got this game retail a long, long time ago, in a galaxy far away.)Multiplayer learning curve is very high as it's all based on your skill with the game.After 11 years, it's still challenging and alot of fun with all the maps/mods/skins the community has made.Unfortunately, Steam gives you the 1.04 version of the game, which is complete♥♥♥♥♥♥ although has a much more active community. My recommandation upon buying this game would be to switch to 1.02a asap. By simply googling "Switch jk2 to 1.02a" you should be able to find it.Another plus is that the source code has been recently released, so we can expect some awesome community stuff for this game :)So, all in all, excellent game, despite how old it is. 10/10

Posted: November 28, 2016
												The best Star Wars game I have ever played!No other Star Wars game I played in my long, long Star Wars-love-Life is a better package of Story and gameplay than this old but gold gem.First off, the Sequel, Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy had even better Lightsaber fights/moves and of course even better lightsabers, but the Game itself itself lacked a little in story and depth.Singleplayer:Jedi Outcast also was the first game I ever "really played", I was only 12 years old and it also was the hardest game I ever played. But to this very day, the game doesn't help you even a little bit. The puzzles don't come with an explanation on how you have to solve it, hell, sometimes you don't even now there is a puzzle, you're just running around for 5 Minutes until you find that on little hole in the wall where you have to do a "force push".Oh and of course nice "guest stars" from the movies.Multiplayer:for an innocent 12 year old gamer-in-the-making, who was a Star Wars fan since the age of 5, this game made me feel like a true Jedi, and to be honest, it still does to this day. The Lightsaber combat (just like in the Sequel) is easy to learn, but hard to master to truly compare against all the other Jedi Masters wandering around in of the best and most fun Multiplayer games i have ever played.An absolute, 100% Recommendation to Star Wars fans, old school FPS fans and 3rd person fighting game fans.

Posted: November 2, 2016
Product received for free
Disclaimer : I got this game for almost nothing in some Star Wars Humble Bundle that i bought for other games a few year back, that's why i'm considering i got the game for free (probably for less than 0.25€)I hadn't played this game for more than 10 years... A friend lent me the game back then, but i never finished it. When i noticed it in my Steam library this week-end so i decided to give it another try. The game is a blend of FPS and third person lightsaber combat. Weapons feel responsive, sound great, and carry the nostalgia of these early-2000s Star Wars games. The graphics are not bad, they aged well in my opinion and i'm genuinely still amazed by the marks left by lightsabers on walls.Now for the cons :* First it's clearly not worth 10€ in 2016.* Some game mechanics are NOT introduced, i discovered that i could use objects, after being stuck for half an hour in the only part of the game that really require using them (The nightvision goggles in the hangar level). Moreover, i only discovered during the final level that i could heal myself using a force power. (Explaining why the last levels were so hard, since medipacs were not provided anymore as i was supposed to use the force...) * Talking about levels, they seem well designed at first glance, but they are a labyrinthic mess. Prepare to run around levels you just cleared for hours before finding out an utterly hidden ventilation grid on the ceiling of a random room that will lead to the next part of it. This happens in every level and i wasn't prepared for that. I still can't believe some levels of this game made it through QA and play-testing, as half of them require you to perform jumps that would have been considered as glitch/skips in any decently-designed game.TL;DR : This is overall a good experience, but kinda frustrating if you are used to modern games that have corrected the youthful errors of this one over a decade. 6.5/10

Posted: May 16, 2013
												The adventures of everyone’s favorite Kyle Katarn continue in another thrilling Jedi Knight game.  And who doesn’t love Kyle anyways?  He’s often been referred to as the Chuck Norris of Star Wars.  And to people that care about Chuck Norris that probably means something.  For me personally, Kyle as seen in these games is more annoying that the Kyle you read about in many of the books.But I’m not reviewing the latest Fate of the Jedi book, is that series still popular?  I’m way behind on my Star Wars novels unfortunately.  We’re here to talk about the next in the Jedi Knight series, Star Wars Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast.  This time Kyle is back, and what starts with a blue milk run quickly becomes a quest fueled by anger and revenge.As the Wikipedia blurb said, assuming anybody actually reads those, Jedi Outcast uses the Quake III: Team Area engine.  This means we are guaranteed to have a pretty good looking game, ID Tech III was first seen in Quake III Arena back in 1999.  It was a beautiful game then, and personally is still a beautiful game.  While there will always be things that could be picked at about the engine, and all the games that run on it, it will remain in my book as one of the best looking engines out there.Jedi Outcast starts off kinda slow, but does pick up its pace once you get your hands on your lightsaber.  Which for me took about 4 hours.  I’m not going to lie, I had a really tough time with this game for some reason.  I’ve played it through in the past, but long enough ago that everything was still new to me.  In fact it wasn’t until I got the lightsaber that I realized that I had in fact play Jedi Outcast.Something about the combat mechanics didn’t agree with me, and while there were some valid complaints.  Things like the Imperial Officers take more damage than the Stormtroopers.  Stormtroopers that are wearing armor while the Officers simply have their dress uniforms.  It would appear that a cotton polyester blend can withstand blaster fire better than the standard issue plastoid armor.  Someone should tell Requisitions about this, could save the Empire billions of credits.You know that line from A New Hope?  Where Ben Kenobi says that a lightsaber isn’t as clumsy or random as a blaster.  Thereby implying that blasters are both clumsy and random.  Well it seems like the developers took that line from the movie and placed it at the core of their combat mechanics.  You could fire a blaster six times without moving the mouse and you’ll hit at six different locations.  The blasters have a fan effect, one that is made worse if you use the rapid-fire.While the previous games had a similar fanning of the blaster bolts, they also had an auto-aim that counter balanced it.  You didn’t have to be a perfect shot, the blaster would make up for what you lacked in skill.  Here they’ve done away with the auto-aim, but left the fanning.  Personally, I don’t think Ben was being very literal when he made that statement.  Not to the extent that this game makes it seem.The story I’d call above average, but still falls to some standard video game issues.  As with many games there are aspects or parts of the story that feel like they are only there for something to do.  Otherwise, were it simply a written story, the segment would have been left out.  But I’d can’t blame a game for these moments, as all games tend to have them.  The developers want to keep the action up, or to showcase a specific feature or ability in the game, and write a level into the story just for that purpose.  Its a common trait, and one that we games have gotten used to.  And the better writers and developers can do this, and blend it into the story so well that we tend to not even notice it on the first pass.Jedi Outcast has the expected character cameos of Luke Skywalker, Mon Mothma, Jan Ors, and Lando Calrissian.  And best of all is that Billy Dee Williams actually voiced Lando, giving the character a little more love than the others.  Although it was a pretty big coincidence that Kyle should happen to be stranded in the same place where Lando is locked up.But convenient coincidences aside, the story holds it own with the average of today.  As well as the bulk of the gameplay, controls, and puzzles have all aged well.  The blasters could use a little work, and perhaps a texture update and you have something that beats a lot of today’s releases.  In fact this would be a great game to get a HD remake.  And there are probably a couple of other things that I just can’t think of right now, but I guess they’re not that important.

Posted: January 21, 2015
												I haven't played Jedi Academy yet, but I can safely say that Jedi Outcast is superior to Dark Forces and Jedi Knight (and far, far superior to Mysteries of the Sith). It has the same fun combat (with a lightsaber, many other Star Wars weapons, and Force powers) that made Jedi Knight such a good game, and it this time it has 21st century graphics, legitimately good voice acting, and a stronger story. It's in the period when Luke's Jedi were headquartered on Yavin 4, and it pits Kyle Katarn against a really great set of new villains while sending him to a lot of iconic Star Wars locations. Unfortunately, the platforming which has been my bane throughout the series is still here. If you love platforming, that will be a plus, but for me, it's the one thing I don't like about this game. (Of course, you can save at any time, so at least it's manageable).I'd say this is the third-best Star Wars shooter ever made (right after Battlefront II and Republic Commando). If you are a Star Wars fan (especially an Expanded Universe lover like me), and/or enjoyed previous games in the Dark Forces/ Jedi Knight series, I recommend this game. If you're interested in the Jedi Knight games but don't want to play something with extremely dated graphics, then this is my recommended jumping-in point.

Posted: January 31, 2015
												What is it about Jedi Outcast that makes it worth revisiting 13 years on (and counting)?  Its predecessor, Dark Forces II, was the last great Star Wars title to be developed in house by LucasArts, at a time when the studio was just at the peak of its creative powers and not yet in decline.  We might even remember DFII as the best shooter of the 1990s, were it not for a little game by Valve that came out just over a year later in 1998.Of course, 4.5 years is an eternity in gaming.  By the time Jedi Outcast hit market in 2002, LucasArts' catchet had taken some major hits, thanks to post-Episode I Star Wars titles that were lazy cash grabs at worst (Jedi Power Battles) or disappointing failures at best (*cough*Force Commander*cough*).  Jedi Outcast was developed by a third party, Raven Software, using the Quake III engine; gone are the quirks and charms of the proprietary engines that powered the earlier games in the Dark Forces series.  Moreover, there's a definite emphasis on straight-up action, rather than the vertiginous, puzzle-filled vibe of the first two titles.So why is this game so much damn fun?Although JO takes a while to hit the ground running with its blaster-only prologue missions, there's an immensely satisfying payoff once the player begins Jedi training.  If wielding the lightsaber for the first time in JK:DFII was a cool feeling, then in JO it was absolutely mind blowing: there is a level of fluidity, control, and power that is unique to Raven's treatment of the lightsaber here, and it's apparent from the moment you first use it.  One can honestly say, even after all these years, that there has never been an objectively better representation of lightsaber combat in a Star Wars game,  And the Force powers?  While some players will miss JK:DFII's RPG-lite system, which allowed one to invest in some powers instead of others, it has to be said that Raven took an interesting approach here: not only are most of the iconic powers retained (push, pull, jump, speed, choke, lightning, etc.), but the leveling is handled so discreetly that it's hard not to be impressed by how POWERFUL you really are late in the game -- and, wow, is it a treat to take down entire rooms of enemies with nothing but your saber, the Force, and the extremely tight controls you'd expect of a Quake III-powered game.The story is hardly award winning stuff, but it's conveyed effectively within the gameplay itself.  As a result, JO has a solid momentum that builds in intensity as the game progresses, until the player is continuing on just to see what crazy cool thing they'll get to do next.  (DO, not WATCH; take note, present-day devs.)Throw in a multiplayer mode that's just about everything you'd want a sabers-and-Force-powers multiplayer experience to be, and there's not much else to say about this game.  Raven might not have made a 1:1 follow-up to the Dark Forces games -- how could they? -- but they more than made up for it by delivering the most exciting Jedi action yet seen in the series, or really any Star Wars title.  I still fire this game up once every several years just to see how it's aged, and each time I'm impressed by how much of a blast it still is.  It's not mere nostalgia at work; it's quality design and honest fun delivered by a talented group of people who set out to capture a very specific kind of action-gaming experience, all while remaining true to the spirit of a classic game series.  If you're a Star Wars fan, or even just a shooter fan looking for something slightly different, this is really one of the most entertaining titles out there.  This game lives up to its pedigree in a big way.

Posted: July 7, 2016
												Star Wars Jedi Knight II - Jedi Outcast was a classic Star Wars game even when came out back in 2002. It is the fourth entry in the Jedi Knight series, and keeps the same great combat and feel of the older games, while still managing to keep things fresh. I play the game on the hardest difficulty, and while it might seem gruelingly hard, the experience is more rewarding than many of the games that have come out in the 14 years since it's release. The gameplay is well polished and most importantly, fun, as it keeps you wanting to go back to it time and time again. The story is also good, pulling upon and expanding the already deep lore of the Star Wars Expanded Universe that takes place after Return of the Jedi. It also features the best lightsaber combat in any Star Wars Game. Ever. All of that combines to create a timeless classic that'll have fans coming back for years to come. I give Star Wars Jedi Knight II - Jedi Outcast, an 8.75/10

												The best Star Wars game I have ever played!No other Star Wars game I played in my long, long Star Wars-love-Life is a better package of Story and gameplay than this old but gold gem.First off, the Sequel, Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy had even better Lightsaber fights/moves and of course even better lightsabers, but the Game itself itself lacked a little in story and depth.Singleplayer:Jedi Outcast also was the first game I ever "really played", I was only 12 years old and it also was the hardest game I ever played. The puzzles don't come with an explanation on how you have to solve it, hell, sometimes you don't even now there is a puzzle, you're just running around for 5 Minutes until you find that on little hole in the wall where you have to do a "force push".Oh and of course nice "guest stars" from the movies.Multiplayer:for an innocent 12 year old gamer-in-the-making, who was a Star Wars fan since the age of 5, this game made me feel like a true Jedi, and to be honest, it still does to this day. 												Best Star wars game in existence.Been playing for at least 11 years and I still love it.(Don't mind the hours through Steam, got this game retail a long, long time ago, in a galaxy far away.)Multiplayer learning curve is very high as it's all based on your skill with the game.After 11 years, it's still challenging and alot of fun with all the maps/mods/skins the community has made.Unfortunately, Steam gives you the 1.04 version of the game, which is complete♥♥♥♥♥♥ although has a much more active community. My recommandation upon buying this game would be to switch to 1.02a asap. By simply googling "Switch jk2 to 1.02a" you should be able to find it.Another plus is that the source code has been recently released, so we can expect some awesome community stuff for this game :)So, all in all, excellent game, despite how old it is. 10/10

Posted: November 28, 2016
												The best Star Wars game I have ever played!No other Star Wars game I played in my long, long Star Wars-love-Life is a better package of Story and gameplay than this old but gold gem.First off, the Sequel, Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy had even better Lightsaber fights/moves and of course even better lightsabers, but the Game itself itself lacked a little in story and depth.Singleplayer:Jedi Outcast also was the first game I ever "really played", I was only 12 years old and it also was the hardest game I ever played. But to this very day, the game doesn't help you even a little bit. The puzzles don't come with an explanation on how you have to solve it, hell, sometimes you don't even now there is a puzzle, you're just running around for 5 Minutes until you find that on little hole in the wall where you have to do a "force push".Oh and of course nice "guest stars" from the movies.Multiplayer:for an innocent 12 year old gamer-in-the-making, who was a Star Wars fan since the age of 5, this game made me feel like a true Jedi, and to be honest, it still does to this day. The Lightsaber combat (just like in the Sequel) is easy to learn, but hard to master to truly compare against all the other Jedi Masters wandering around in of the best and most fun Multiplayer games i have ever played.An absolute, 100% Recommendation to Star Wars fans, old school FPS fans and 3rd person fighting game fans.

Posted: February 22
												One of the last Star Wars classics Lucas Arts made back in their prime. This and Jedi Academy has the best lightsaber combat I've ever seen in a video game. An absolute must play, as long as you don't mind the game being over a decade old.Positives:-Top tier lightsaber combat that isn't matched by any other series-A wide array of force powers for you to use as the game progresses. You can force choke stormtroopers and fling them around the room like a rag doll. Later in the game, you can just enter a room and burn everyone to a crisp with lightning-Familiar Star Wars setting and musicNegatives:-Level design paired with the aging graphics engine makes most levels confusing to navigate instead of challenging8/10
